name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: On 1 July, following the recommendation of the Advisory Committee on the Conduct of Members, I decided to impose a sanction on Mr Sleyley. Jan Zahradil for failure to comply with the declaratory obligations laid down in Articles 3(3) and 4(2) of the Code of Conduct, which may have given rise to a conflict of interest. The penalty is a warning.  The decision was notified to the person concerned on 7 July. Pursuant to Rule 177 of the Rules of Procedure, a Member shall have two weeks from the notification of the penalty for an internal appeal against that decision to the Bureau of Parliament.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: We shall now proceed to the first voting time today.  We shall vote on the dossiers on the agenda. The first voting time will be open from 9.15 a.m. to 10.30 a.m. The votes will be conducted in the same way as yesterday. All votes will be taken by roll call and Members will be able to check their votes and the results of the votes by consulting the document to be published on the plenary's website. Explanations of vote may be submitted in writing. Exceptionally, only explanations of vote with a maximum length of 400 words will be accepted.  I declare the first voting time open. You have until 10.30 am to vote and the results will be communicated at 2.15 pm.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, a moment's attention: I wanted to make a statement to you. As you know, the new national security law came into force in Hong Kong last week. The situation is becoming more and more dramatic: every day that passes brings with it reports of further imprisonment, arrests and violence, there is no longer any freedom of assembly or freedom of speech, even books have been taken away in libraries and schools. These are extremely worrying developments, which concern us. I admire and admire the courage and determination of the citizens of Hong Kong, many of whom are risking their personal freedom in defence of maintaining a democratic, free and open society. What was once a democratic reality, where the rule of law, fundamental freedoms and a high degree of autonomy were part of everyday life, is now in danger of being mortified. As Parliamentarians, we must show solidarity, take a stand against the erosion of freedom and the growing authoritarianism we are witnessing. I think I am interpreting the sentiments of all my fellow Members in calling on the competent authorities to respect international commitments and fundamental freedoms. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments)

name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item in the agenda is the joint debate on statements by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy - on the 2019 Annual Report on Human Rights (2020/2688(RSP)), - on stability and security in the Mediterranean and the negative role of Turkey (2020/2706(RSP)) and - on the situation in Belarus (2020/2707(RSP)). I would point out to Members that there are no spontaneous speeches and no blue cards in this debate.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, since we do not have a lot of time, let’s go directly to the matters on the Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the world 2019. One important subject that the report highlights is the link between human rights and the environment. I took part in December in the 21st EU-NGO Human Rights Forum, and I was struck by the testimonies of human rights defenders from across the world. In 2018, 77% of human rights defenders killed worldwide were working on environmental issues. These are very sensitive issues and economically very important. The protection of the rights of indigenous peoples against, among others, land-grabbing is of central concern. We must strengthen our efforts in this regard. The report equally highlights the link between the digital transformation of our societies and human rights and democracy. New technologies bring opportunities to promote human rights and democracy but also generate uncertainty and challenges. I therefore welcome the pioneering debate of the European Parliament on the need to regulate ethical aspects of artificial intelligence. This year will mark the 25th anniversary of the Beijing Declaration on gender equality. Unfortunately, according to UN statistics on women, a third of women around the world continue to suffer from some kind of violence in their lives. Despite the fact that we rely so heavily on women to make up the much-needed workforce of carers, teachers and nurses, women are generally experiencing the biggest socio-economic consequences of the pandemic. There is also some good news and progress in human rights policy and democracy. For example, let’s highlight the decision by Chad to abolish the death penalty; the decision by Sierra Leone to overturn the ban on pregnant girls attending school; Sri Lanka brought child labour down to 1%, through the pioneering ‘Child Labour Free Zones’, concretely, more than 60 000 fewer children in child labour compared to 10 years ago. Slowly but firmly, we are advancing in this field. Some societies in Tunisia, Sri Lanka and Gambia made democratic improvements and, unhappily, autocracy has expanded in 2019. Resistance against dictators has also been growing. I would like to say more things about this report, but I have to turn – according to the agenda – to the second item that you have titled: ‘Stability and security in the Mediterranean and the negative role of Turkey’. That is how you titled the second point in the agenda. I have just returned from intensive discussions in Turkey and Malta. In the previous week, I visited Greece and Cyprus to demonstrate the European Union’s solidarity. It is clear that the stability and security in the Mediterranean requires our collective engagement. Years of conflict in Libya and in Syria have been impacting this region, directly affecting our interests and security in terms of uncontrolled migration, terrorism or political instability from the Sahel to the broader Middle East. Turkey is also affected by this situation and is active in conflicts both in Syria and in Libya. In fact it is one of the most important actors in both conflicts. We have had important discrepancies regarding Turkey’s action in north-west and north-east Syria. Last October, the Council firmly condemned Turkey’s military operation in north-east Syria, yet we must also acknowledge where our interests coincide. Turkey has been showing solidarity and generosity towards more than 3.5 million Syrian refugees and has supplied cross-border humanitarian assistance to those displaced by the recent brutal fighting in Idlib. By the way, I have to regret strongly the decision of the Security Council not to continue opening the border between Turkey and Idlib in order to bring humanitarian assistance. In Libya, we need to work better together to launch a real political process. I remembered it also yesterday in my intervention in front of the Security Council of the UN, stressing the importance of the Berlin Process and our commitment to implement the UN arms embargo through our means (inaudible). With Operation IRINI we will continue to monitor closely suspect trafficking, regardless of provenance or destination. In the Eastern Mediterranean, Turkey has been showing a worrying assertiveness, with an increased number of flights over Greek islands in the Aegean Sea, drilling operations in the Cypriot Exclusive Economic Zone and signature of the Maritime Memorandum of Understanding with Libya, which we do not recognise here in the European Union. On these issues, we have been sending clear messages to Turkey. We are determined to protect the principles, values, borders and sovereign rights of the Member States, and we will also continue working for a political solution in Syria and Libya. Turkey is an important partner, a candidate country and a NATO ally. The current negative trend in our relations – as I told our Turkish colleagues, the Foreign Affairs Minister and the Defence Minister a couple of days ago in Ankara – needs to be stopped and reversed. The dynamics of retaliation do not make the Mediterranean a more secure and stable zone. This will only be achieved through dialogue and negotiations where discrepancies exist, and they do. This is what I have been discussing with Turkish colleagues on my last trip, stressing that we have many common interests on which to build. On Monday, with the Foreign Affairs Ministers, we will examine a possible way forward. The third and last issue is Belarus. Let me start right out with the latest developments. I reassure you that we pay very close attention to the situation on the ground in the context of the 9 August presidential elections. We are concerned about the restrictions on freedom of assembly and speech, including the reported detention of peaceful protesters, bloggers and journalists. The harassment and persecution of the leading opposition candidates has to stop. Fundamental freedoms have to be respected, and each candidate and voter must be able to exercise their civil and political rights. We expect to be invited by Belarus as soon as possible to observe the upcoming presidential elections. We have reacted to recent developments, calling for the immediate and unconditional release of all arbitrarily-detained persons. We will follow closely these elections in order to reinforce the sovereignty, independence and freedom of Belarus, which is the only way to pave the future of prosperity for its citizens. Belarus has demonstrated an active participation in the Eastern Partnership. We have achieved tangible benefits for the Belarusian citizens, in particular the Visa Facilitation Agreement, which entered into force on 1 July. The EU is Belarus’s second-largest trade partner, and close economic cooperation is of mutual interest. Due to our geographic proximity, our ongoing dialogue, among others, on how to improve standards on environment and climate change is essential for all Europeans. In the absence of a legally-binding framework agreement, the conclusions of the EU-Belarus Partnership Priorities remains an important objective, and I believe that having an agreed set of political priorities, including on human rights and nuclear safety, would provide us with more transparency and accountability in our relations. We should remain open to further development of our relations with Belarus and continue supporting Belarus’s sovereignty and independence. However, this development can only be based on positive steps in the area of democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms. This brings me back to my initial words. The 9 August presidential elections will be very important in charting our way forward and in defining our relations.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, High Representative Borrell, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Borrell, for the work he has all asked. I would like to refer to Turkey in today's debate. We have a lot in common with Turkey. We have common economic interests, we have a common history, Turkey's NATO membership, the solidarity there, many Turkish people live in Europe and also many Europeans in Turkey – and, of course, Turkey's commitment to the refugee issue. We have to keep that in mind, there is a lot of partnership.  But something is changing – obviously – and that is why the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has requested today's debate, because we are concerned, for example, the permanent attacks by the Turkish military against the Greek border, the illegal drilling, the activities now in Libya, where there have itself been conflicts with French warships, and, of course, also internally: freedom of the media, civil society, and on top of the abuse of migrants on the external border. Turkey is moving massively away from the values, from the ideas of the European Union, and that is why I would like to start by saying 'thank you' to Nikos Anastasiadis and Kyriakos Mitsotakis, who share responsibility for us Europeans on the external border, on the Turkish border. This became clear in February, particularly in the attacks carried out by the illegal immigration, and the message is: 'We will not be blackmailed by Erdogan'. That is the message behind it.  We must make it clear that the problems in the region are not Greek-Turkish, not Cypriot-Turkish problems, but EU-Turkish problems. We must not leave the two states there alone. The message we have for President Erdogan is that the European Union is ready for partnership, also ready to come back to the partnership, but we need a partner to participate. The European Union is not naive. We also have our ability to respond, and the customs union, which is of vital economic importance to Turkey, is one of those tools. I would also like to see honesty in relations. The accession talks we are having with Turkey have been a mistake. There has been too much disappointment on the Turkish side, and there is no willingness in Europe to take in Turkey in many areas. That is why we should end this chapter and open a new chapter in partnership. The accession talks should be brought to an end and we must enter into a new partnership with Turkey. We hope that Ankara is prepared to do so.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr High Representative, today we are looking at yet another report on human rights and democracy in the world and, unfortunately, we cannot say that there have been major changes since the last report. The changes are slow. Nevertheless, this is not, ever, just another report.  Year after year, this report tells us about the victims of racism, of indigenous people expelled from their lands, of political prisoners and journalists, human rights activists and environmentalists persecuted, silenced, murdered. It tells us about people who suffer torture and inothermite treatment. It speaks to us of those who flee war, persecution, hunger and who, so often, end up finding death, very close to us, on our borders, where they only hoped to find an opportunity for a dignified and safe life. This report tells us of millions of people who ask for justice and respect for the rights we aspire to: universal and indivisible. From people who, more than for what we say today, here, wait for what we are able to do tomorrow.  It is up to us to assume the uncompromising defence of multilateralism and the values of the European Union: to fight impunity and act, to defend the International Criminal Court against the ignominious attack being made on it, to implement the European system of sanctions against perpetrators of human rights violations, to establish a mandatory mechanism of due diligence, to prevent products obtained through human rights violations and environmental attacks from enter our trade chains and to build a European pact for migration and asylum that honors the humanist values of the European Union.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, Mr High Representative, the presentation of this report is important this year, because it also closes a roadmap on the strategy for democracy and human rights. There are positive aspects, you mentioned them, but there are huge negative elements to this report. I would also like to point out that, in a positive way, climate change and biodiversity loss are recognised as a very important threat to human rights, and I think it paved a good way for us. But I would like to point out that 2019 stands out as a very bad year, because it has been a very good year for populism; a populism that advances, deteriorates democracies, makes them more fragile and therefore deteriorates human rights and freedoms. Increasingly, we are seeing the weakening of our democracies from within, using democratic institutions to generate autocratic regimes. And they do, we see it, we are seeing it, attacking the judiciary, attacking the press, fundamental freedom of the press. That is why, Mr High Representative, the Democrats cannot in any way allow insult, harassment, persecution of the press to be naturalized. We can only fight it firmly. That is why, in order for Europe to really be an assertive Europe, effective, consistent with human rights, we must work now more than ever for multilateralism, and that means defending international legality, because defending it defends the rights of all. We also have, high representative, to enable and accelerate the implementation of the 2030 Agenda, especially its objective 16. And we finally have to work, of course, for more democratic societies, for greater democratic resilience, which includes promoting a rights-based approach to migration, addressing forced displacement and reducing the factors that cause irregular immigration.

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the way in which The report lists a number of successes around the world. My concern, however, is that these achievements are taking place in a political vacuum and often have little more than a fig leaf function. The greatest humanitarian catastrophe in the world today is taking place in Yemen: women and children are being targeted by militias. Since the total dissolution of social structures, there have been poor hygiene conditions, under which horrible diseases are rampant.  Meanwhile, the leaders of the various warring parties outside Yemen are resonating in security from the chaos they have wreaked. And yet we read so little on this subject. We have outsourced the problem to the UN, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. It is not even mentioned in this Parliament or in the relevant committees. We have a whole section on religious freedom, but nothing specific about the appalling persecution of Christians in West Africa, the persecution of entire communities on the basis of their Christian faith. In the report, I noticed a section on strengthening the economic participation of Afghan women – in itself, of course, a good and highly laudable purpose. My problem with this, however, is that, while this support for Afghan women is necessary, we have done nothing about the political situation in which these women have to assert themselves. We do not say a word about the corrupt electoral process, the extrajudicial executions or the fact that large parts of society are being marginalised by the new government. Let us approach these issues with political pragmatism in order to bring about real change. Let us take measures to protect the most vulnerable, rather than to fine-tune trivialities.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we stood here in January this year, and in Parliament’s resolution on the 2018 annual report we called on the Council and the Commission to establish a coordinated procedure for granting visas to human rights defenders. And now I’m standing here again: nothing happened. Even worse, when I asked the Commission about it this March, I received the following answer: the Commission is, and I quote, ‘not aware of systemic problems faced by human rights defenders fulfilling the necessary entry conditions in being granted short-stay visas’. Seriously? Özgür Gür was supposed to speak at a round table at Parliament on 15 October last year. He’s a 25-year-old LGBTI activist. He applied for a Schengen visa with the Belgian embassy. The MEP hosting the event even called the embassy. Still he didn’t receive a visa. Tomorrow, Özgür Gür is facing trial in Turkey for organising a non-violent protest for LGBTI rights. There are so many more people like Özgür Gür, because to get a visa, you should be married, have a proper job, a regular income, you should not have been in prison or in conflict with state authorities. Well, human rights defenders living in oppressive countries can rarely fulfil these criteria, precisely because of the work they do, because of the work we ask them to do and we encourage them to do. And then the Commission speaks of no systemic problems? Mr Borrell, you know this as much as I do. Human rights defenders are our partners. Without them, we can do nothing when it comes to promoting human rights globally, and their space is shrinking. And now our own visa policies are shrinking their space even more. So I really urge you to get together with Commissioner Johansson to stop this injustice and adapt the Visa Handbook, to make sure that they can travel and network and go to conferences. Because our role as the European Union is to support and protect those fighting for democracy and human rights, and not to make their lives even more difficult.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Mr Borrell, the messages keep coming in on my iPhone, almost daily. Reports of discrimination, threats, violence and even deadly attacks. And that purely because one is Christian. Yesterday, a report about a woman in India, murdered while collecting wood in the forest, probably by Hindu extremists. She leaves behind four children aged 6, 8, 12 and 17.  The Commission's initial intention not to extend the mandate of the EU Envoy for Religious Freedom, against the background of all these reports, raised a great deal of questions. I am therefore very pleased that the Commission has come back to this and is now having the EU envoy for religious freedom return. Unfortunately, such an envoy appears to be very much needed. In addition, it is very important that we provide this post with sufficient staff and budget. More than during the previous mandate, when the unit dealing with religious freedom was very, very small. I hope that the Commission will be reassured on this point as well.  Freedom of faith is not high enough on the European agenda. There is a lot of work to be done in this respect. The European Commission must exert pressure in concluding or renewing trade agreements with countries where there is too little freedom of faith. Trade is good, but faith is better and more important. It is also important that we keep each other on our toes here in the European Parliament, and that we also keep the Commission on the same level on this important issue.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President. Mr Borrell, the European Union says that in 2019 it was a leader in the promotion and protection of human rights. For me it was the year in which the Mercosur Agreement was closed, while Bolsonaro burned the Amazon or promoted the unprotection of indigenous peoples.  2019 was the year carola Rackete and other NGOs were criminalized and defamed for rescuing people from certain deaths in the Mediterranean, while Parliament – this one – rejected a resolution calling for the resumption of search and rescue operations in the Mediterranean; the year in which international law was ignored and a trade agreement was ratified with Morocco that includes the occupied territories of the Sahara; the year in which human rights violations committed by crimes by governments such as Erdogan or Al-Sisi continued to be whitened.  Judge for yourselves. I'm clear about that. I believe that we must stop giving lessons and we must start to set an example, to comply with human rights in our trade agreements, to comply with human rights in the Mediterranean, to comply with human rights also on European territory.

name: Leopoldo LÓPEZ GIL
text: – Madam President, Mr High Representative, the report we are debating today marks the end of the implementation of the Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy (2015-2019). One of the objectives of this plan, set out in the report, is to combat torture. An important tool for this is human rights dialogues with third countries, as was done with Cuba in October 2019, where there are still, unfortunately, prisoners of conscience, arbitrary detentions and medical missions considered modern slavery by the United Nations. Another priority of the Union's external action is to promote democracy and the rule of law in the rest of the world. In 2019, eight observation missions and seven expert missions were carried out to support electoral processes. These resources could ensure the democratic and negotiated transition in Venezuela, with free, fair, transparent elections, nullified the regime's attempts to corrupt democratic institutions and unlawfully depose the leadership of political parties. Mr High Representative, use all the instruments at your disposal to restore democracy and human rights in countries suffering from your absence.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, Mr High Representative, before COVID, the human rights situation was, in some respects, and in many parts of the world, in decline. The pandemic has only exacerbated an already extremely tense situation in these countries and the most vulnerable populations are paying a high price.  We have seen youth movements, protests by young and old, before COVID, but which were prevented or even repressed during confinement. I will mention, for example, only the pro-democracy movements in Hong Kong, the Hirak in Algeria, or movements in Lebanon and Chile. These movements were and are a symptom of deep problems. We have seen it in our democracies, in the United States with the Black Lives Matter movement, and we have seen it in Europe as well. It is true that we in the European Union have succeeded in developing a strong and ambitious human rights policy. And I welcome your initiative to establish a new sanctions mechanism to address these realities - realities that violate human rights. But our action demands more coherence in all our policies. European policies must respect the treaties and in particular Article 21 of the Treaty on the European Union. Whether it is trade policy, migration policy, humanitarian policy, development policy or climate policy: all these policies must respect the principle which is the do not harm principle. Never should a European policy generate, encourage a weakening of human rights in the world.  For this we need more ambitious European regulation, we need more efficient and inclusive regulation with civil society. We also need to fight impunity by supporting the International Criminal Court.

name: Barry ANDREWS
text: – Madam President, High Representative, I want to take this opportunity to call on you to appoint a Special Representative to the Syrian conflict. I acknowledge that there is a UN envoy, but we are not the UN. I acknowledge there’s no clear political path at the moment, but I believe that is the only way to a sustainable peace, because we cannot leave it to the Russians, for the fate of the people of Idlib. Tomorrow, as you know, the cross-border resolution delivering humanitarian aid to two million people comes to an end. It was vetoed by both Russia and China who have decided to cut off aid during a pandemic to two million people.  I worked for a humanitarian organisation in Syria for four years and I cannot express the shame I feel for the international community’s inability to protect the people of Idlib. For 10 years the UN has been unable to protect against forcible disappearances, chemical attacks and targeting of civilian infrastructure, and now it cannot even deliver aid. So ahead of next year’s 10-year anniversary, I call upon you today to appoint a Special Representative that can begin the process of developing relationships for a sustainable peace in Syria.

name: Isabella TOVAGLIERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is certainly a good thing for Europe to monitor respect for human rights in the world. However, it should also investigate, and above all denounce, perhaps with greater determination, the violations of fundamental rights that take place at home, on its Own Community territory. Violations that are increasing exponentially as a result of massive migrations from countries of Islamic tradition and faith, which bring with them illegal, archaic and sexist practices. I am referring to female genital mutilation ( already 600 000 cases in Europe, of which 70 000 in Germany alone), forced early marriages and practices such as the imposition of the veil, against which women in Iran – a black country of human rights – are currently fighting at great cost in the deafening silence of the international community. Denouncing and repressing these phenomena at home is certainly more inconvenient than updating world statistics, but this is no longer a procrastinating imperative, which requires Europe and individual governments to have political courage which, unfortunately, has so far been lacking.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Madam President, in the Annual Human Rights Report, the range of activities and initiatives in the area of business and human rights is certainly to be commended. Yet, rights which are not legally enforceable are rights in name only. After many years of hard work here in the European Parliament and in civil society, finally, we will see that a growing number of Member States and the Commission are increasingly accepting that mandatory legislation is needed for business and human rights.  At the end of April, there was a milestone event when the Commissioner for Justice, Didier Reynders, committed to a legislative initiative on mandatory human rights and environmental due diligence obligations for companies operating in the EU area. The German Council Presidency now has committed itself to an EU action plan on business and human rights. This is indeed long overdue because the EU has been very diligent about its Member States adopting action plans, but as we say, at least in Finnish, the shoemaker’s children sometimes don’t have shoes. The EU still lacks this action plan and we only can welcome it.  We can also see that now would be a very timely moment for the EU to start to make a meaningful contribution in the international negotiations among the UN frame for business and human rights because we have started to act at home, so please ask for the mandate from the Member States to start these negotiations.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: – Madam President, the EU is committed to the defence of human rights around the world. However, in order to be effective, the EU must have a moral authority that it doesn’t have. And it doesn’t have this because Europe tolerates, for example, arbitrary detentions of social and political leaders committed by Member States such as Spain. This is why its efforts are not credible to third countries. You mentioned Turkey. When one year ago the Turkish regime decided to remove Kurdish mayors from office – mayors democratically elected – its Interior Minister justified this with the precedent of the removal by Spain of Basque and Catalan elected pro—independence politicians who were removed without any trial.  Moreover, I have been unable to find in its report any explicit reference to the persecution of the Kurdish people, contrary to what happens in other reports on human rights, like the one from Human Rights Watch. Recover Europe’s moral authority, Mr Borrell. Dissidents from all around the world will be grateful.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, Mr High Representative, respect for human rights is a hallmark of the European Union and its Member States.  Our foreign policy logically cannot ignore this dimension. I therefore encourage the European External Action Service to continue its work and reports to promote respect for human rights in the world. In addition, I would like to remind you that, in general, the countries that respect human rights and the rule of law are also the ones that support an international order based on international law and peace, which is what We Europeans want.  Furthermore, the Foreign Affairs Council in December last year agreed to start work on establishing a comprehensive sanctions regime against human rights violations, which also recalls the document on the priorities of the German Presidency, which began a few days ago.  I would like to know in more detail what objectives it pursues, the state of these works... Of course, I think it is essential to improve the mechanisms for the enforcement of sanctions. You can't repeat what happened in Madrid last January.

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his In my minute, I am focusing on Turkey, because it systematically breaks international law and destabilises the whole region. While we are discussing this, Turkey is occupying several regions of northern Syria, and Kurdish women who remain there, especially religious minorities such as the Yazidi women, are being terrorised. We are discussing this, and Turkey is unilaterally intervening in the Libyan civil war, thereby setting in motion a spiral of violence. We are discussing this, and Turkey is openly threatening the EU Member States Cyprus and Greece. Europe is watching as a country with domestic problems tries to overplay them through an increasingly aggressive foreign policy, tramples human rights underfoot and continues to destabilise the region.  Just as important to me is that we must also respect the human rights that we demand from others – the key word: our external borders. Only then can we credibly demand respect for human rights internationally.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Madam President, I very much welcome this discussion, which once more shows that our Union is based on values. I very much agree with what has already been said by the majority of colleagues, but let me make another point.  The EU spoke on minority issues several times in 2019. During the Human Rights Council and the UN General Assembly, the EU spoke with the special rapporteur on minority issues. At the Forum on Minority Issues, the EU took the floor on the topic of education, language and the human rights of minorities. There was a European Regional Forum on Minority Issues organised in this House. At all these meetings, it says in the annual report, the EU highlighted its policies on inclusive education, celebration of linguistic diversity and the rights of minorities.  But do we lead by the example we are trying to set? The special rapporteur has stressed that statelessness is a minority issue; it is one of his priorities. But have we discussed statelessness in the EU – like the hundreds of thousands of stateless persons in the Baltic States?  The UN also considered it a right of minorities to learn in their mother tongue. As minority schools are being closed across Europe, was this issue brought up? What I want to say is that our participation in various minority platforms is based on telling others what they’re doing wrong. Our message would be much more convincing if we were able to set a proper example ourselves.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, respected colleagues, in order to have the right to doc about the human rights situation outside the European Union, we must primarily turn to ourselves and see that these same rights are not respected in Catalonia, i.e. in Spain, that political persecution is being pursued that we are silent on here, we have not spoken at all in this Parliament so far on such an important issue.  Furthermore, we have violations of fundamental human rights when introducing quarantines. Certain countries do so through governments, while other countries such as the Republic of Croatia have transferred all powers to headquarters that have absolutely no real basis to limit people's right to work, the right to treatment and the right to freedom of movement.

name: Maxette PIRBAKAS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted today to mark with my words the memorial history of the peoples of Europe. I have proposed to the President of the European Parliament a resolution which seeks to reconcile the European people on our common history, particularly with regard to the Overseas.  The legacy of Afro- and Indo-descendants who have suffered slavery, as well as all past and modern slaverys, must not be forgotten. It is the memory of the Overseas That I represent here in the European Parliament. Tackling past slavery based on human trafficking, such as combating modern slavery by denouncing an ultra-liberal economic model that tends to general poverty.  As Martin Luther King said, an injustice committed somewhere is a threat to justice around the world. Let us pay tribute to the memory of our slaves and reconcile to build a future without discrimination and to find free and equal European peoples. An avè zàt, an la pou zot, dear Guadeloupeans, dear Martiniquais, dear Reunion Islanders, dear Guyanese.

name: Arba KOKALARI
text: – Madam President, democracy is under attack, the rule of law is backsliding and individual rights are being undermined. We are seeing the rise of authoritarian regimes, like in China and Russia. When we say that the EU must act to protect human rights, that has to mean that we have to give the EU the right tools to do so. That means that we need to introduce a global human rights sanctions regime as soon as possible – because those who commit human rights abuses have to face sanctions. The EU has to protect human rights defenders that risk their lives for freedom. We need to make sure to remove the unanimity principle in the Council on human rights matters so that the EU’s voice on human rights can become stronger because if we don’t protect and act on human rights, who else will do?

name: Marc ANGEL
text: – Madam President, I congratulate the efforts of the European Commission and most Member States for their global promotion of gender equality and LGBTI rights. The European Commission must continue to enhance its efforts in promoting and defending these values, be through political action or financial support. Both are important.  This is now so crucial because we have to counter the discriminating and very well internationally organised anti-gender movement.  I also appreciate our multilateral approach and the leading role of the European Union international fora defending LGBTI rights and gender equality. However, leading role means leading example, otherwise we lose all credibility. I call on the European Commission, the Council and also to this high House to not only speak up but also take swift action when it comes to  the most recent backlashes to LGBTI rights in some of our Member States, namely the LGBTI-free zones in Poland, the discriminating legislation in Hungary against intersex and trans-persons. The Commission and Council must act and I say that we have to be coherent and stay credible when it comes to promoting human rights worldwide and encourage human rights defence.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, according to your very words, High Representative, in the introduction to this report, the COVID pandemic has changed, perhaps forever, our world and our societies. I would like to be able to say that this experience has served to renew a feeling of humanity and compassion, but in many cases the emergency has been on the contrary, in so many parts of the world, used and exploited to strengthen the repression of human rights, censorship and discrimination. We must be proud to be part of an institution that must not be afraid to speak out strongly in defence of human rights, even when the interlocutor is an important trading or political partner. It is therefore essential to strongly reaffirm that the EU is and will continue to be a beacon in the dark, at the forefront of the fight for respect for human rights and democracy, on the one hand by making its voice heard loud and clear in international institutions and by defending multilateralism, starting with full support for the International Criminal Court, once again under unacceptable attack from the United States. On the other hand, it is essential for the EU to mobilise all the instruments at its disposal against major violators: as the UK has done, the EU must follow up its commitments and adopt a comprehensive regime of human rights sanctions as soon as possible.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, fáiltím roimh an tuarascáil seo agus ba mhaith liom an tArdionadaí a mholadh as ucht na dea-oibre agus na ceannaireachta atá á dtaispeáint aige san áit thábhachtach seo. Agus freisin, tá moladh ag dul do Eamon Gilmore, Iar-Thánaiste na hÉireann atá ina Ionadaí Speisialta do na Náisiún Aontaithe ó Fheabhra na bliana seo caite. Tá géarghá leis an dea-obair seo mar a fheicimid sna díospóireachtaí éigeandála a bhíonn againn anseo sa Pharlaimint. Tá éagóir á déanamh air a lán daoine timpeall an domhain, go háirithe daoine atá ag seasamh suas da na daoine atá i mbaol; iriseoirí, na meáin i gcoitinne, agus mar sin de. Féach air cad atá ag tarlú do mhná timpeall an domhain uilig; is rud scannalach is. Agus féachaimid air an tSín, teacht anuas air dhaoine agus leatrom á dhéanamh air dhaoine de bharr a reiligiún. Caithfimid seasamh suas do na daoine seo seo seo go minic is sinne an t-aon ghuth láidir cumhachtach atá acu.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr High Representative, the report on human rights and democracy which we have an opportunity to examine today has a lot of premonitory. The integrated approach to situations on the ground, including the development of strategies and action benchmarks, the focus on multilateral dialogue, proved to be even more appropriate in the face of the health, economic, social and political fractures exposed by the pandemic.  We cannot hesitate in the face of the progression of authoritarianism and populism in the world, the closing of borders, the increase in intolerance and the asphyxiation of freedoms.  The path of the European Union must be even more the way of promoting human rights and multilateral dialogue. I only have a minute, Mr. High Representative, so I wanted to focus on the situation that is being lived, specifically, in Mozambique, in the province of Cabo Delgado. It is a situation in which human rights safeguards are at enormous risk as a result of a combination of fragile governance, pressure stemming from the exploitation of new gas deposits, reduced socio-economic conditions and growing signs of religious intolerance.  It is a case where a humanistic and multilateral approach can make all the difference and gain a character in our choice and positioning in the world. European action is needed, Mr. High Representative.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, thank you very much, High Representative, for your report and for your work. For us, the human rights situation in the world is not only worrying, but a sign of the deterioration of some of the major global trends we see, our multilateral system and human rights protection mechanisms, the questioning of international law and humanitarian law, and the increasingly common emergence of rulers who believe that , on behalf of the majority and democracy, the rights of those who do not vote for them can also be violated. They also speak in their report of some groups and of the systematic questioning and violation of children's or women's rights, the questioning of the rights of migrants and vulnerable persons, even within our borders. But I want to end by referencing Latin America and the worrying emergence, increasingly, of killings and violations of the human rights of indigenous leaders, leaders of human rights defenders and leaders of defenders of the territory and the environment. This is also a challenge for the European Union and we look forward to working together.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, from this step of the European Parliament I denounce Turkey for the continuing and escalating threats, blackmails and attacks against Cyprus and Greece, two Member States of the European Union. At the same time, I warn the European Union that if it does not take immediate and decisive measures today to stop Turkish aggression, tomorrow will be too late and the consequences will be uncontrollable. If all of us in the European Union believe that solidarity is its fundamental value, one thing we have to do: to call on the Member States of the European Union to allocate their naval forces to the European Union, so that it can defend and safeguard its external borders, which are the borders of Cyprus and Greece.  I am proud and happy because I belong to the European People's Party, which adopts this position and unreservedly supports the positions in favour of Cyprus and Greece. At the same time I endorse the position of the leader of the European People's Party, Manfred Weber, that, if Turkey continues along this line, the Customs Union must be suspended. But we as the European Parliament must also cut Turkey's accession funds and exclude Turkey from the multiannual financial framework, because that is the only way Turkey can understand the problem it is creating in Cyprus and Greece. Strong European Union, strong, solidarity means ... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Mr. High Representative, Mr Borrell, the relationship with Turkey is complex, but it is a relationship.  Why do I say this no-brainer? Because there is an obvious interest of Turkey in compartmentalizing the relationship, creating disjointed and unarticulate pieces. We have offered Turkey the most, which is to be a member of our club — even if it sometimes hears them seem like punishment – and the framework, therefore, of the relationship has to be that of a candidate country. This means a progressive alignment of Turkey with all European Union standards.  The situation of the relationship is bad — you acknowledged it on Monday – because there is a lack of trust, a substrate of lack of trust that affects all areas of the relationship.  The exemption is frozen, with a brutal deterioration in human rights, in visa liberalization.  And it must be said: Turkey has not complied with the frameworks it has to follow to access; regarding the Customs Union, we fought at the World Trade Organization; in migration we receive an unfounded accusation that it is not complying, when European public opinion thinks precisely otherwise; and in foreign policy, this idea of assertiveness is being, I believe, misused.  With Greece and Cyprus, we cannot stand in solidarity because we are Greece and Cyprus and therefore cannot act as a mere mediator... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I have a question for the esteemed High Representative. I really wonder whether President Erdoğan is still in favour of joining the EU, don’t you? Look at Turkey’s recent actions. They go completely against all European values and interests. Its illegal drilling activities in territorial waters; its violation of the UN arms embargo and its intimidation against EU and NATO allies that are enforcing the Libyan arms embargo – not to speak about its purchase of the Russian missile system and the arbitrary arrests of human rights activists, lawyers, judges and journalists. Last but not least, its repeated threats and blackmail to open up the gates to Europe. The list could go on.  So to me, High Representative, Turkey’s accession wish is a joke! Yes, Turkey is a strategic partner, both for Europe and NATO. It’s a neighbour and I do believe in the necessity of a strong partnership, but Turkey continues to move further away from the EU.  This Parliament has been clear about its position. This authoritarian Turkey cannot join the EU.  I thank you for your efforts in continuing the dialogue with Turkey but I also ask you to be very clear and frank with Turkey that there can be no upgrade of relations, in whatever form, as long as its actions do not change and as long as Turkey does not show readiness for serious reforms.  Thank you very much and good luck.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr. President, Mr. High Representative, how long will we tolerate this situation? European civilization has, as we know, an enemy at its doorstep. It is no longer skirmishes that Caliph Erdogan addresses us, but military aggressions. What is Erdogan's regime? It is a double bet: that of the union of all Muslims under the banner of political Islamism and the pre-eminence of Turkey in the Mediterranean. The Austrians, Hungarians, Serbs, Greeks, Cypriots, English, French and Russians and so many other European nations have constantly faced this dual project since the fall of Constantinople. Today, the European Union prevents them from pursuing this historic vocation. But we turn a blind eye when Albania and Kosovo become Turkish protectorates on our continent. Worse, we are trying to speed up the accession process. In Libya, we reproduce the same mistakes that we made in Syria, looking kindly at these militias paid for by the Turks. In fact, when we witnessed, a few days ago, an incident akin to an act of war between France and Turkey, at the level of the navy, Europe remained almost unreaction and without solidarity. Mr. High Representative, how long will we tolerate these attacks? How long will we continue this illusory process of Turkey's accession to Europe, which does not share any of our values, none of our projects? I believe that today, in this situation, Europe must be firm. I will simply end with a wish: if we want to save peace, if we want to save our borders today and ensure that they are not controlled, in every way, by Turkey, I ask you to be firm. I hope that your name does not go down in history alongside those of Daladier or Chamberlain, that is, those who have shown weakness in provoking... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Tineke STRIK
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the High Representative for his speech. The title of this security debate gives the impression that we are dealing with one evil factor in the Mediterranean that is responsible for all security threats. Such a simple narrative is attractive but not very helpful, as it leads us nowhere. The situation near our borders is highly complex, and most worrying is the lack of influence that we have, both in Syria and in Libya, and this really should be reversed. But we will only gain more influence with a more regional and comprehensive approach. The people in Libya are overrun by many states who are competing for their own interests and influence, and the citizens of Libya really need our strong support for the establishment of a state where democracy, the rule of law and accountability prevail. Security threats will remain as long as Libya is a failed state. Turkey is one state interfering for its own interests over there, but so are Russia, France and Italy, and others. Compliance with the Berlin Process is of utmost importance, and it’s disappointing that even EU Member States don’t always respect the agreement. So I ask the High Representative which possibilities he sees for increasing the effectiveness and expanding the scope of Operation IRINI, despite the blockage by Russia in the Security Council. Apart from that, we should invest more in regional stability, and this starts with the region closest to us: Cyprus. We need to find a solution for the conflict that we have neglected for so long. But also in North Africa, involving Libya’s neighbouring countries would really contribute to a more sustainable solution. I agree with Mr Borrell that, despite Turkey’s bad track record, we share common interests, and the neighbouring countries are key to us. We cannot simply remain in a deadlock and act as if we do not need to cooperate or narrow it down to cooperation on the EU—Turkey Statement. So I support his approach to rethink the strategy, but not only for security reasons – also to promote human rights.

name: Assita KANKO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, gas drilling in Cyprus, belligerence in the eastern Mediterranean, annihilating Christian communities, buying a Russian—made S—400 missile system, threatening French ships, transferring Jihadi fighters from Syria to Libya, blackmailing Europe with migrants if we do not support their actions in Syria. Colleagues, I have to ask, with friends like these who needs enemies? The past few months have shown that Turkey under Erdoğan cannot be a close and trusted ally of Europe. This is the behaviour of an autocrat and we cannot continue to entertain autocrats on Tuesday and then on Wednesday claim we are a continent based on democratic values. The time has come to admit that the current framework for our talks with Turkey, the membership framework, is completely out of touch with reality. It’s time for a fundamental strategic rethink of EU—Turkey relations. We can have a relationship that is built on trade, but we should not be naive to the fact that both our values and interests are not converging, they are diverging. Friends do not behave in the way that Turkey has been behaving. So, if we cannot be friends, let’s take the Turkish approach and have more transactional relationships. Maybe we cannot be friends, but Turkey needs to be a better neighbour and you can do that.

name: Giorgos GEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Mr Borrell, nowadays the Eastern Mediterranean is on fire, countries are falling apart and people are being killed in order to re-divide territories and wealth. Turkey is leading this effort in a pirated way to become ruler of the region. He already illegally owns half of Cyprus. It is now intervening in Syria, Libya, Iraq and Somalia. It also threatens Greece and illegally drilling in the Cypriot EEZ. Europe is proposing dialogue to it. To have a dialogue, Mr Borrell, but to define with dignity the limits, context and stakes of this dialogue. How does Turkey respond? He responds with threats. He's working on immigration and saying he's going to unleash new waves of refugees.  Europe must finally realise that it is not only Cyprus and Greece that are now under threat; Without strict sanctions and legitimate comprehensive solutions to the region's problems, Turkish threats threaten to drown Europe itself in the end. Europe's tolerance of the beast can ultimately eat it down. Is that what we want?

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Mr President, the recent Turkish escalations in the Mediterranean and the violation of the territorial integrity of Greece and Cyprus are challenging our partnership. As the European Parliament, today we should once again make it very clear that Turkish activities, like the illegal drilling in the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus, the violations of Greek airspace or the attacks on the Greek border are simply unacceptable. Turkey must take concrete steps to de—escalate the current situation.  I would like to thank the High Representative, Josep Borrell, for his initiative to start, to restart a dialogue with Turkey. Indeed, Mr High Representative, we need to talk urgently. We need to talk urgently on the basis of firm principles and fully united as the EU-27.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr President, we have repeatedly criticised Turkey for its drilling activities in Cyprus’s exclusive economic zone, tensions it causes in the Aegean Sea,  and its engagement in Libya. Finally, the Council has decided that a regime of restrictive measures should be put in place against Turkey,  which the S&D Group supports. The list of open issues with Turkey continues, with the Turkish maritime claims and violation of Greek airspace that have led to a significant deterioration in relations between Greece and Turkey. Turkey has also been continuously interfering in Libya’s internal affairs, violating the UN embargo and undermining the efforts to find a political solution under the auspices of the United Nations. We call on Turkey to show restraint, respect the sovereign rights of Cyprus and refrain from any such illegal action. If Turkey’s illegal actions continue, the European Union must respond appropriately, in full solidarity with Cyprus and Greece as European Union Members.

name: Nathalie LOISEAU
text: Mr President, Mr High Representative, you said a few days ago that the situation between Turkey and the European Union was, I quote, far from ideal. Like you, I know the charms of diplomatic language, but sometimes you have to know how to call a spade a spade. For too long, the Turkish regime has turned its back on our values, especially in the area of human rights. Now too often, Turkey goes against our interests. Its presence in Syria weakens the coalition's fight against Daesh. In the Mediterranean, it drills illegally, flouts international law and undermines the sovereignty of Greece and Cyprus. In Libya, it sends Syrian mercenaries, some of whom are jihadists, it violates the commitments it made at the Berlin conference and increases the risk of a partition of the country. On 10 June, a Turkish warship attacked a French ship operating as part of a NATO mission, of which Turkey is a member, to enforce the arms embargo in Libya. This hostile behaviour on the part of an ally is of particular gravity and cannot remain inconsequential. It is not diplomatic language that must be used today vis-à-vis Ankara, Mr High Representative, what we expect from you is the language of firmness.

name: Vincenzo SOFO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Solana, since 2002 we have given Turkey over EUR 16 billion to bring it into Europe and to make it manage the problem of immigration for us. We have allowed Erdoğan to keep us under blackmail with the threat of migrants in the Balkans and now we are doing the same thing, we are risking the same danger in the Mediterranean, where the Turkish advance foments chaos and where their NGOs indoctrinate peoples with neo-Ottoman ideology. The EU, which is having so many problems helping Italy economically, should explain to us what those 16 billion have been used for. To strengthen the European project? No. To strengthen Erdoğan's imperial projects if anything. It is suicidal to contract the management of Europe's borders to those who want to weaken Europe, just as it is utopian to hope to stabilise the Mediterranean with those who want to conquer it. The solution, therefore, is not to continue kissing Turkey's feet, but, if anything, to strengthen France, Spain, Greece and above all Italy, with its south, which are the only true guardians of Europe's security and future in the Mediterranean. If we want to stabilise the Mediterranean...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Damian BOESELAGER
text: – Mr President, as Chancellor Merkel said yesterday, we cannot look away. We must address the European migration and asylum crisis. Yes, we must establish security, but what is security? As long as EU countries are closing down their harbours to migrants and refugees, there is no security in the Mediterranean. As long as COVID—19 is being used to create de facto detention camps on the Greek islands, there is no security in the Mediterranean. As long as EU money is being used to fund Libyan coastguards and to circumvent asylum law, there is no security in the Mediterranean.  Security in the Mediterranean can only be reached by applying asylum and maritime law, by allowing people to disembark after days on freighters and by relocating people out of the camps on the Greek islands. Day by day, we endanger the lives of human beings, of our brothers and sisters, as our Christian Democrat friends would say, but we can change and we can learn from our mistakes. First, we need to set up a European asylum system that is centred around the right to asylum and around the asylum interview. Second, we must acknowledge that we are a continent of immigration and we must create new channels and new pathways, and create new opportunities for people to enter the European Union.  (Applause)

name: Emmanouil FRAGKOS
text: Mr President, we are here today to talk about security in the Eastern Mediterranean, security that everyone who listens to us knows is threatened solely by Turkey. And it makes sense to threaten, at a time when Turkey is usurping Greece's mineral wealth by illegal agreements, trafficking illegal immigrants, violating Greek borders every day and possessing a neo-Ottoman expansionism. And at a time when all this is happening, we have seen Mr Borrell talking to Mr Çavuşoğlu and pretty much telling us that the European Union is ready to negotiate with Turkey on Greece's mineral wealth.  Until when will the European Union turn its back on its members? And not only is it turning its back, but directly and indirectly supporting a country that, according to thousands of complaints, in the 21st century recruits underage children aged six and seven and in the name of a religion calls on them to witness and sacrifice themselves for Turkey. All of you who talk about human rights, what do you have to say about this situation? In conclusion, and for the reasons I have mentioned to you, as a Greek Solution we demand that all funding from the European Union to Turkey be interrupted and that all dialogue with it be interrupted.

name: Özlem DEMIREL
text: Mr President, Mr Borrell, I would like to thank Mr Borrell for his work on Yes, the escalation in the Mediterranean is worrying. The rhetoric between the Greek and Turkish sides is intensifying. Erdogan loses popular support, slipping from one economic and political crisis to the next. That is another reason why he is currently relying on his military strength. Hence the conflict in the Mediterranean, and therefore the conflict in Libya. Colleagues, yes, you are right to be upset about Erdogan, his human rights violations, yes, you are concerned about the situation in Libya. But why, then, do you stick to the refugee deal with President Erdogan and work with Libyan warlords? You are talking about an arms embargo by the irini military mission. But Member States continue to sell weapons with a cheerful price! Stop arms exports, for example to Turkey! That would be more effective. The whole argument and the whole debate is about gas and oil, not only the ACP, but also France and Italy are involved in different sides for their oil companies. I say: all troops must get out!

name: Loucas FOURLAS
text: Mr President, Mr Borrell, when you allow someone to attack you, blackmail you, insult you and you do not react, basically all you achieve is to create a situation that is constantly getting out of control and a country that is constantly being broken up. That is what happened to you, as Europe, with Turkey, a country that is acceding – if possible! – a country that asks you to negotiate with it what it has stolen. And the most outrageous thing is that he finds ground.  Two Member States of the European Union are under constant threat from a country that holds European territory and illegally entered European waters for drilling, a country that has attacked neighbouring countries in order to bring peace, and has never left. We don't want you to tell us we're right. We know we're right. I want you to tell us what you will do to support us in practice, in fact and not in words. How will you save, even the hystatis, the dignity of the European Union, which was left to be blackmailed by Mr Erdoğan. It is time for the principles and values of the European Union to finally prevail, not the interests.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Mr President, a large part of Turkey's political staff invests in nationalism and tension. Mr Erdoğan's strategy opens up issues that were closed 100 years ago by the Treaty of Lausanne. Its dangerous revisionism touches Greece, the Eastern Mediterranean, Libya and Syria and, as you know, recently said defiantly that it wants to turn Hagia Sophia into a mosque, provoking Christians all over the world.  In this escalation the answer cannot be just words but a comprehensive plan. Of course this plan will involve an arms embargo and not to have Operation Peace, but for those who carry the weapons to Libya to be the Turks themselves. Of course, sanctions must be imposed on those involved in the illegal actions of the Cypriot EEZ. Of course, if Turkey continues these challenges, the 'sudden death' of the Customs Union must be imposed, because Turkey's economic dependence is greater than Europe needs Turkey. Finally, we want peace and prosperity in the wider region. But if the Council chooses tolerance, the cost to the Peoples of Europe will... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Chrysoula ZACHAROPOULOU
text: Mr President, Mr High Representative, in Syria today and in Libya, and for a long time in Greece and Cyprus, in this Chamber and in Europe in general, we have often thought that Turkey's attitude is a distant problem, a Mediterranean problem.  But on the contrary, it concerns us all: Turkish interference raises a major geopolitical issue, which jeopardizes our European sovereignty. In the face of violations of international law and the law of the sea, Europe observes more than it acts. On our doorstep, we risk a Syrianization of the Libyan conflict and a humanitarian disaster.  Faced with the risk of new waves of migration, in the face of terrorist threats, Europe will also be powerless and divided. Once again, President Erdogan is putting us in the face of our inertia, at the mercy of his blackmail. Europe cannot let Turkey take control of the eastern and central Mediterranean. "Borrell!" Χρειάζεται άμεση δράση της Ευρωπαϊκής Ένωσης.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: Mr President, on three three times, on 10 June, a French frigate was illuminated by Turkish ships, an act of deliberate military aggression that normally calls for a fire response. France has suspended its participation in NATO missions in the Mediterranean, but no reaction from the Commission, the Council or Parliament, institutions literally on their knees before Erdogan. Illegal drilling in the territorial waters of member countries, blackmail and extortion with migrants, used as a means of pressure on the European Union, objective complacency with jihadism in Syria and Libya, massacre of the Kurds, our allies in the fight against Daesh: nothing is done, the submission of the European Union to Turkey is total. Your majority continues to negotiate an accession process with the Ottoman imperialist, your majority pays billions to the autocrat Erdogan to keep the migrants at home. This submission, which was displayed in your speech, Commissioner, leaves Cyprus, Greece and now France alone to defend themselves. I went to the Greek-Turkish border, I saw the Greek army holding, alone, our European borders. I saw the bridges mined so they could be destroyed in the event of a Turkish attack. It is high time that the Union and Parliament put an end to accession negotiations with Erdogan, the arched enemy of our European nations.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, Mr High Representative, colleagues, I wonder what else Erdogan needs to do to understand the true nature of his policy?  I also remind you of the famous facts: Erdogan occupied and continued to illegally occupy part of Cyprus, waged war in his own territory against the Kurds, waged an illegal war in Syria, waged war in Libya, tried to occupy the Mediterranean because of access to oil and gas. Today, the turkish newspapers broke the news that they had decided to turn Hagia Sophia into a functioning mosque and had already started this. I remind you: Hagia Sophia is the mother of all churches, it is no coincidence that she is called "the mother of all churches". What else does this man have to do to understand his nature and behavior? Why? Perhaps he should offer to make this hall an acting Muslim temple? When will you finally understand that Turkey is not a European country and will never be like this: neither territorially, culturally, nor civilly or politically? How long will this circus continue with Turkey's membership negotiations in the European Union? How long will European funds continue to pour in to help Erdogan pursue his Islamist policies and his hostile policies to other countries? Mr High Representative, one thing is clear: the sooner these shameful negotiations are put to an end, the better and, please, take a look at the transformation of Hagia Sophia into a mosque.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Mr President, will we remain impassive for a long time in the face of Turkey's repeated provocations in the Mediterranean?  The aggressive attitude of a Turkish frigate against a French navy vessel that was acting under the aegis of NATO must alert us all. I find that this incident has elicited very little reaction, whereas it illustrates, in my opinion, the inconsistency of the so-called European pillar of the Atlantic Alliance and gives reason to those who speak of NATO 'in a state of brain death'. More broadly, while we are garging about a 'power Europe', an 'independence Europe', I think it is actually our european imperiousness that has enabled Turkey to establish its quest for power in the Near and Middle East. Let us remember Syria, where we were unable to help our Kurdish allies. Let's look at what is happening in Libya today. So, yes: Mr Erdogan is taking advantage of our weaknesses, our divisions, our hesitations and it is high time that Europe was respected. We owe it to the Europeans, but we also owe it to the Turkish people, whom we do not confuse with their rulers.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, describing the relationship between Turkey and the European Union at the moment, you have described that report as 'negative trends'. I would ask you to use less naïve terminology, if possible, because what is happening between Turkey and the European Union is not a negative trend, it is the failure to respect the normal rules of institutional cooperation. What has happened is not the continuation of an application for membership, but the decision not to join, replaced by the strategy, rightly referred to as neo-Ottoman, which we have seen applied in Cyprus, Greece, but also in Egypt, Tunisia, Algeria and Libya. It means replacing Europe in the Mediterranean. I would remind you of the words of a great popular, Aldo Moro, who described this tragedy by talking about Europe not as a continent in the Mediterranean, but saying that Europe is the Mediterranean.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Erdogan and his government in Turkey are a threat – a threat to the population of Turkey, a threat to the population of the Middle East and a threat to Europe. Turkey's actions have long been alarming. This both leads to escalating conflicts in the MENA region and risks further new conflicts in the Mediterranean region.  In Turkey, Erdogan is hitting the opposition hard with threats, hatred and violence. In the Rojava region of Syrian Kurdistan, Erdogan-branded bombs fall on the population. And violations of Greek waters and airspace, while occupying northern Syria and drilling within the Cyprus Exclusive Economic Zone, are all a violation of international law.  We should also know that Erdogan's threats, hatred and violence continue to spread in country after country in Europe. Erdogan-controlled media in Turkey have in recent months carried out a witch-hunt on three of my Socialist colleagues in the Swedish Parliament. The Vice-President and Your High Representative, Josep Borrell, dialogue is always important and your visit to Turkey on Monday was therefore welcome, but how long should we have to deal with Erdogan ... (The President took the floor from the speaker).

name: Bernhard ZIMNIOK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The migration crisis has been simmering since 2015, and yet neither the Commission nor the so-called pro-Europeans around Merkel are seriously prepared to take appropriate measures to finally solve these problems. Phrases and words are not enough here! From a self-chosen position of weakness, the EU prefers to be blackmailed by the despot from the Bosphorus and to continually pay tribute to him. He is waging war in Syria, against Kurds and Yazidis, and stands alongside the hardcore terrorists in Idlib. Against Greece, he uses the migration weapon to make us docile. Through his military presence in Libya, Erdogan not only controls the so-called Balkan route, but also controls the flow of migrants across the Mediterranean route. Erdogan is not part of the solution in the Middle East and the Mediterranean, he is the problem!  Let us finally react in the only language he understands: let us stop all support and turn the tap on him economically! Let us finally close our external borders and put an end to the criminal smuggling of seawatch and co. on the Mediterranean route!

name: Carlo FIDANZA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 'within half a century Turkey will emerge as one of the strongest powers in the world, sailing towards greater goals' – this is how the new Sultan Erdoğan spoke in February of this year, before the Parliament in Ankara: a declared will for power, a neo-Ottoman design that is becoming increasingly evident. First support for Islamist militias and aggression against the Kurds in Syria, then illegal drilling off Cyprus, against Italian and French interests, then intervention in Libya alongside the Tripoli government, and again the unscrupulous use of migratory pressure, first on the borders with Greece and Bulgaria and then in the central Mediterranean, through Libyan and now algerian traffickers It is blackmail against Europe, but it stutters and continues to pay. And then there is support for political Islam in Europe, through the Turks living on our continent, who are even called upon to colonise us by bringing our children into the world; the penetration into the Western Balkans and other areas of Africa, from Sudan to Somalia, as witnessed by the story of the Italian Silvia Romano, freed by Al Shabab only after Turkish mediation. In this alarming context, the mild restrictive measures wanted by the European Council are not enough. Fratelli d'Italia has always believed that Turkey, by its history, geography and culture, is not part of Europe, as we understand it. The time has come to finally revoke turkey's pre-accession status and say no, once and for all, to Turkey's accession to the European Union.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, Turkey is now a lawless state. It’s pushing forces underground in Iraq against the will of the Iraqi Government, it encroaches on the sovereign territory of Syria whenever it feels like it, and it is ignoring a UN weapons embargo in Libya. But Turkey couldn’t do what it does in northern Iraq and Syria without a green light from the United States and, sadly, the EU is subservient to the US. We hear so much about European values, but we are playing a pitiful role in the region. The Caesar sanctions introduced by the US are a blanket punishment of the people of Syria and we are saying nothing about it. And yet we’re happy to support war criminals like bin Salman and Netanyahu.  Mr Borrell, you talk about the Turkish showing solidarity because they’re blocking up 3.5 million refugees for us. What’s the future of the refugees? Europe doesn’t want them. They’re not going to stay in Turkey forever. Why don’t you work with Syria and ignore the threats from the US because, until Syria recovers, the refugees can’t go back. It looks like now you don’t want them to go back. Cop on to yourselves!

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The pandemic should have taught us that humanity must stick together, and the citizens of Turkey are as much appreciated as all the people of the world. But The leadership of Turkey, which is rejected by many citizens, perhaps by the majority, is doing a lot of things wrong. From North Africa to Vienna favourites, to the federal capital of my native Austria, is destabilised, needlesticks are set, they are escalated rather than de-escalated, as the phase of the pandemic should teach us all at the latest. The arms embargo on Libya is being circumvented, bad blood is being spread against NATO partners in the Mediterranean, and riots are being carried out in Vienna, presumably with the support of the Turkish leadership – in the middle of Europe. The candidate status must therefore be stopped. We must therefore put an end to pre-accession aid, because the Turkish leadership has been signalling for a long time that it is not ready for Europe.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, it is important that we are discussing Turkey's illegalities in the European Union and in the Eastern Mediterranean more broadly today, but that is not enough. Top mistakes in history, my dear Mr Borrell, are repeated because those in power are not taught by the mistakes of the past. Let me mention one: the policy of appeasement towards the Nazi regime. In the end, humanity paid for this greatest mistake with rivers of blood, because we were not taught by history and the supporters of that policy were condemned by history. The credibility of the European Union is therefore judged in the Eastern Mediterranean. Are we going to defend international law and European law and our values or are we going to continue to sell arms to Turkey? As we speak, Germany is selling state-of-the-art weapons to Turkey, which Turkey will use against the interests of the European Union. These are neither credibility nor values, my dear Mr Borrell.

name: Francesca DONATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Dear High Representative, in your report you call for dialogue with the Turkish Government, expressing an incomprehensibly accommodating position towards a regime that has always violated human rights and international law, responsible for the protracted Syrian conflict, which has already claimed 400 000 lives and displaced 11 million. Erdoğan is allied with Syrian terrorist jihadists, which he also uses as mercenaries in Libya, also violating the arms embargo here. For years it has been receiving billions in pre-accession funds from the European Union and to stop syrian refugees arriving at our borders, but today it is blackmailing us, demanding more funding and free camp in the Middle East and North Africa for its expansionist aims. In the eastern Mediterranean, it has carried out aggressive actions against Cyprus and Greece, and within Turkey it violates democracy and human rights with an authoritarian regime that suppresses dissent and discriminates against Christian and Kurdish minorities. So far, the European Union and the UN have been shamefully inerti. Today it is our duty to condemn these violations once and for all, imposing the necessary sanctions and interrupting all cooperation because neo-Ottoman Turkey...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: – Mr President, Mr Borrell, to last March's crisis, where the Government of Erdogan threw thousands of migrants at the gates of the Union, the military incidents in France, Greece and Cyprus, as well as the new threats made during their own visit to Ankara, are added.
