And that is due, as you are hearing here in this European Parliament, to the lack of political determination of the Union and the lack of defence of the strong, Christian values that make up Europe. Nevertheless, in response to a letter sent by all Vox Members to you requesting that the million-dollar payments to Turkey be suspended, he replied that the money does not go all to the Government and that you are very much in favour of maintaining those payments. Well, let us continue to pay an invoice of EUR 1.7 billion to a country which we cannot consider a partner. Similar situation is that in the Maghreb, where we also have several countries that are un collaborative and challenging in controlling illegal immigration.  We therefore call on you to immediately suspend all payments to third countries that do not clearly cooperate with immigration policies and that Turkey's entry procedure into the European Union be terminated.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Mr President, coming from a Mediterranean country, I can rightly say that this cradle of European civilisation plays a crucial role for the security and well-being of all European citizens. When its security is threatened, we must react as one. We feel the menace that our European compatriots in Greece and Cyprus are facing from the provocative actions by Turkey. These actions are violating international law and creating tensions and conflicts with the European Union. In recent months, we have seen similar behaviour regarding the refugee crisis and the attacks on European borders. That time, we sent a strong message that we stand strong and united in protecting our borders. This behaviour should stop immediately. I call for dialogue and the search for a European solution, as it is only by a dialogue that we can avoid a further escalation that history will not forgive. The Mediterranean has, without saying, the world’s most important shared heritage. We call on Turkey to take on board European values in order to find a way to build a shared future between us.

name: Andreas SCHIEDER
text: Mr President, High Representative, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work Erdogan is moving away from European values with great strides. No, in fact, Erdogan has already distanced himself from European values – and also from human rights and international law. Inside, by the imprisoning of democratically elected mayors, parliamentarians, journalists – there are already 90 000 detainees in Turkey for political reasons. But also by the incitement of far-right mob on the streets in Europe, as for example in Vienna last year, in that the Grey Wolves were also sent to the streets by Erdogan. And foreign policy through Turkish airstrikes on Syria, on Sinjar, on the Kurds, by the Turkish navy, which is aggressively targeting Cyprus, but also in Libya. Therefore, we must not only ask ourselves whether Turkey can continue to be a partner in NATO, in the Council of Europe, but also: are sanctions not appropriate, even before the accession negotiations are abandoned?

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: Mr President, a Turkish warship that involves French sailors, Turkish frigates repulsing a Greek helicopter carrying out cargo control, arms and militia deliveries to Libya despite an embargo, military incursions into Syria, Iraq and a duplicity with Daesh... Is it still necessary to talk about the plan to turn Sainte-Sophie into a mosque so that everyone is well aware of Erdogan's provocative and belligerent intentions? This is clearly not enough for the representatives of the European Union. I went to the greek-Turkish border last March, and like everyone else, I saw the neo-sultan's aggressiveness towards our continent, towards a state, Greece, which you have abandoned to Turkey's unacceptable migratory blackmail. Diplomacy is a balance of power before which you have abdicated. The European Union must now more than ever put an end to this game of dupes towards Erdogan, to which you have for too long submitted. The aggression of our borders like that of our army is not acceptable. Economic sanctions must be imposed, starting with the suspension of all economic aid paid to Ankara with the money of the French and that of the European peoples.

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Mr President, in 1935 Mustafa Kemal turned St. Sophia's Basilica into a museum that reflects the Christian heritage in Turkey and the universal vocation of this heritage. Today, Recep Tayyip Erdogan decides to redo a mosque. The message is clear: the falsification of history carried out by the Turkish government today, as on the Armenian genocide, on the deportation of Greeks from Asia Minor or on the persecution against the Kurds, unfortunately serves a dangerous future project. Europe must get out of denial. The road to Turkey is worrying, not only for the Near and Middle East but for the whole world and for Europe in particular. This is evidenced by the recent and serious tensions in the Mediterranean Sea. And I would like to reiterate here our support for the Greeks and Cypriots who are directly under pressure and blackmail. In the face of this, Europe today is powerless and we are still being offered to send money to Turkey for our farmers, which will feed funds that we do not know exactly how to control, of course. It is time to get out of denial and, to begin with, to put an end to this accession procedure which is only an absurd fiction.

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Turkey, in Erdoğan's Turkey, we are faced with an authoritarian spiral, a lack of respect for democratic values, the removal of mayors, opposition representatives and representatives of civil society. This is incompatible with our values. Erdoğan is not only a problem for what he does inside Turkey, but also for what he provokes outside it: think of the role played in the shocking Libyan scenario, in Syria and against the Kurdish people; Let us think of the reckless use it makes of the presence of refugees, including with regard to European countries. However, we must ask ourselves a question: what is Europe's role here? What is our responsibility? We must condemn Erdoğan, of course, and we must continue to do so very clearly, but we must also be aware that Erdoğan has found an empty space, generated by the culpable absence of Europe's strategic choices, first and foremost in relation to the centrality of the Mediterranean and the lack of a strong global policy to promote human rights.

name: Vangelis MEIMARAKIS
text: Mr President, we all want good relations with Turkey, provided that it respects us. It will respect the rules of international law. He won't trespass on them the way he's been provocatively behaving lately. Otherwise there is no point in this dialogue, because this relaxed behaviour gives Erdoğan space to provoke, blackmail, arbitrarily. Even Hagia Sophia, this world heritage site, wants to turn into a mosque. It challenges us because this is not a military operation. It's a blow to our culture. It's a blow to Christianity and for us Greeks it's a blow to our hearts.  That is why we were all surprised by the images the planet saw during your visit, Mr Borrell, to Turkey. After Erdoğan refused to meet you, humiliating the European Union once again in your face, as he had done at the joint press conference with Mr Michel and Mrs Ursula von der Leyen, and he left ostentatiously and did not go, you heard the minister insult three States of the European Union and you did not reply to him. You didn't have the reaction you should have and it was like giving absolution to Turkey. But you should have mentioned the Council's conclusions...  (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Anna-Michelle ASIMAKOPOULOU
text: Mr President, Mr Borrell, just yesterday here in this Chamber, Chancellor Merkel praised our role as MEPs in explaining to the citizens the policies of the Union. So I ask you, Mr Borrell, how can I explain to my fellow citizens in Rhodes, Karpathos, Kasos and Crete the illegal Turkish drilling that grossly violates international law? How can I explain to my fellow citizens in Evros, Lesvos, Chios, Samos, who welcome thousands of refugees and migrants showing unprecedented solidarity, the fake news of Turks presenting them as murderers of young children? And how can I explain to my fellow Christians that Hagia Sophia can be turned into a mosque? And how can I explain to my fellow citizens that when the Turkish Foreign Minister openly threatens the Union and refuses to recognise one of its Member States, Cyprus, you, our High Representative, smile by accepting a hand sanitetic gift? If, after all this, Mr Borrell, I am called to explain to my fellow citizens that what we need instead of sanctions is a constructive dialogue with Turkey, then at least, as a mark of respect, the smiles are missing.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, when Brexit started first, many people in Ireland felt that the European Union would throw Ireland under the bus at the last moment to appease the British. That did not happen. We were shown wonderful solidarity, which was much appreciated, and that solidarity is now needed in relation to Greece and Cyprus, where a powerful neighbour is violating Greek airspace and drilling illegally close to Cyprus. I think we need to send a strong message to Turkey that it cannot continue violating the sovereignty of our Member States, that all Member States are equally important to us, and if they do not react properly then we have to take whatever actions are necessary to stand up for our Member States. Europe’s strength is its unity. That unity we showed in relation to Brexit and the Withdrawal Agreement must now be shown in relation to Cyprus and Greece.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, Mr Borrell, as you know, Greece has already concluded the agreement on the limits of the Exclusive Economic Zone with Italy and is working in this direction with Egypt as well. Greece's objective is to negotiate with Turkey on the demarcation of the continental shelf and the Exclusive Economic Zone and, in the event of non-agreement, to jointly appeal to the International Court of Justice in The Hague. Turkey formally threatens Greece's territorial integrity and challenges international agreements. You know, the demarcation of Greece's EEZ with Turkey is not a bilateral matter. Greece will be able to contribute to the diversification of energy suppliers in the European Union by increasing its autonomy. That is why the European Union has every interest not only in formally and verbally reiterating its position on the EEZ, but above all in putting pressure on Turkey to make it compulsory to settle the EEZ either by negotiation or through mutual recourse to The Hague.

name: Rasa JUKNEVIČIENĖ
text: – Mr President, the situation in the southern EU neighbourhood is dangerous. It has to be seen in a wider context, not just in relation to Turkey. There are a lot of talks about EU strategic autonomy in the security area. The processes that have been developing in the Mediterranean for several years now confirm that we have to act, not only talk. When the EU is not acting, others do – in this case, Turkey and Russia. Even more so, as different EU Member States support different sides of the conflict in Libya. Where is the EU strategy here? Today we have to speak about the capability of the EU to act near its borders, to act in coordination with NATO. This would be the kind of EU strategic autonomy in which our voters could believe. (Applause)

name: Andrius KUBILIUS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, High Representative, after 26 years of the authoritarian rule of Lukashenko, the Belarusian people are loudly demanding real change in their country, and it can happen on the 9th August presidential elections. It’s a different situation today than it was before. Opinion polls are showing that more than 50% of Belarusians want real change and only a minority want Lukashenko to stay. The mood of the people of Belarus reminds me of our Baltic Singing Revolution of the 1990s. Belarusian rock bands are coming out with popular songs against the regime. People of the cultural elite are bravely coming out on YouTube with their anti-regime statements. Bloggers are creating a real online network of resistance. And all of them are persecuted by the regime. Lukashenko’s main competitors, Babaryko and Tikhanovskiy, are in prison. During the last months the list of internationally-recognised political prisoners increased to 30, including famous opposition leaders like Pavel Sieviaryniec. Today we need to send three clear and loud messages. The first to the citizens of Belarus: we are in solidarity with you in your demand for change and we shall defend your right to decide on the change in your country to become a normal a European democratic country. Second, a clear message to Lukashenko and his nomenclatura: if, on 14 July next week, opposition candidates are not registered by the authorities, if political prisoners and candidates are not released from prison, and if the people on the street are threatened and persecuted, there will be sanctions – personal sanctions. And third, a message to ourselves: we need to stand up and to defend the rights of our neighbours.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, just on our border in the heart of Europe, our neighbours, the people of Belarus, again are being deprived of their fundamental rights. We are with them: žyve Belarus! But our message to President Lukashenko is clear and recurrent: we strongly condemn this ruthless crackdown and appeal for the immediate release of all who have been unjustly arrested. Lukashenko has been in power for 26 years, but for most of this time political life in Belarus appears dormant. This is no longer the case. In these circumstances the EU must be equipped with a strategic and responsive policy towards Belarus. A policy that includes clear red lines and smart conditionality. Against this background, could the High Representative tell us how the EU policy towards Belarus will be justified to address the ongoing and future situation? If there is no strategy, could you please provide this Parliament with a written statement in the coming weeks?

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, today in Belarus, we are witnessing a systematic and continuous imitation of election procedures created for a solemn purpose: to extend the three-decade-long authoritarian regime. Grave election violations were recorded by the OSCE’s Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights (ODIHR), and the same pattern is being applied in the ongoing presidential elections. However, the regime failed to adequately assess the mood of the Belarusian people. Public dissatisfaction with government policies has exceeded people’s patience, and the appearance of new presidential hopefuls has ignited hope of change. The Belarusian regime is stuck in the past. In order to preserve power, it continues along the path of repression, intimidation, prosecution and mass arrests. Peaceful protesters and passers-by are beaten and kidnapped by the KGB, and also bullied and threatened by the state media. The main opposition contenders, Viktar Babaryka and Syarhei Tsikhanouski, remain imprisoned. The Belarusian regime has gone back to the time of prisoners of conscience. Three years after his release, former prisoner of conscience, Nikolai Statkevich, is back in jail. Another opposition leader, Pavel Sevyarynets, just had his sentence extended. In order to prevail, the Belarusian regime is ready to use any means, even a rush to launch the Astravyets Nuclear Power Plant, which does not comply with international nuclear safety standards. The project is the most western-located (just 20 kilometres away from the EU external border) nuclear installation funded and developed by Russia. It is another Trojan horse for European safety and energy security.  I call on the EU institutions to elaborate a comprehensive strategy for Belarus. It has to be based on a European perspective, respect for the principle of sovereignty, democratic governance, free and fair elections, a pluralistic society, and international standards of nuclear safety. The European Union has to remain open and supportive to the Belarusian people. In no way can our support for Belarus to overcome COVID-19 be associated with support of the Belarusian regime. Finally, the European Union must learn a lesson from the early removal of sanctions in 2016 and keep the sanctions option open and under constant surveillance.

name: Viola VON CRAMON-TAUBADEL
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. In many eastern partnership countries, we are dealing with broken democracies and autocratic systems. But in no state is the discrepancy between a European society that shares our values and a president who oppresses them as obvious as it is in Belarus. It is almost tragic to see a country that is geographically located in the middle of the European continent, with its government, as far removed from our values as Belarus. The death penalty is still being carried out there! In Minsk, we are not only dealing with a president who denies Corona and instead recommends tractor rides and sauna visits, but we also face crucial elections. Never before has there been so much dissatisfaction with Lukashchenka, who has been in power for 26 years. People want change: they take to the streets, they spend hours registering their presidential candidates. But Lukaschenka is afraid of competition, he does not want to accept a serious candidate. All promising competitors have been arrested on flimsy grounds, are in prison, and are sometimes severely tortured in the old KGB manner, all in the middle of Europe. Before we continue to negotiate with the regime, we are calling for three points from Minsk, which must be fulfilled. One thing, as Mr Borrell has said, is that there must be a fully equipped OSCE Election Observation Mission. Secondly, the President must not dare not register the promising candidates such as Babaryka and Zichanouskaja. That would be a slap in the face to millions of Belarusians eligible to vote. Thirdly, all political prisoners must be released unconditionally and immediately. These are our minimum requirements. This is what our EU institutions must do on the ground and we here in Brussels, together with the Member States and with the German Presidency. The enforcement of this demand is also an important test of the EU's credibility in Belarus.

name: Manu PINEDA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, let us be clear: you are bringing this debate on Belarus here today because the elections are coming in an allied country in Russia and you want to influence the results. They are openly practicing the constant interference they report in other countries.  And let me remind you that these movements have been dangerous in the past. When changes of government are promoted at any cost, we can end up supporting governments with "Nazi" ministers, as we have already done in Ukraine.  The eastern border of the European Union is now a heavily militarized territory and, e later this year, NATO exercises have taken place off the Border of Belarus, with more than 36,000 soldiers, most of them Americans. Is this escalation of the peoples of Europe interested? Of course not. It only serves to fuel Mr. Trump's new Cold War.  They must at once park this vision of international relations typical of bygone eras. We need an autonomous and sovereign foreign policy that bets on multilateralism and stability on our continent, not sanctions and constant confrontation with our neighbors.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, that was quite remarkable what the previous speaker said here. One had the impression that he was an advocate for Mr Lukaschenka. Take note of the fact that, after 26 years, the people of Belarus really have their muzzle full – to put it in German – of this regime and that they want change and that it is not us who are calling for it, but the people there.  It is important that the ODIHR, the OSCE's election observation, is invited. We should insist, High Representative, and we must insist that the political prisoners be released and that all candidates be admitted. There is actually a broad consensus, obviously with the exception of the Left Group, and it is good that we have this broad consensus here in this House. It is also important that the election campaign can take place freely. I hear that there are already decrees on the ground banning the election campaign in the city centre. That, too, is a tactic of the regime. We should not allow them, we must denounce them, and let us really leave our words in Belarus ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: Mr President, High Representative, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work We have a very worrying situation in Belarus, which will get even worse by election day on 9 August. We are seeing arrests, we are seeing arbitrariness, we are seeing the immobilizers of opposition figures, we are seeing civil society activists being locked away, peaceful demonstrations are being banned.  What can we do as the EU? We need a strong joint response, a strong joint response from the EU Commission and the German Presidency. The influence of Berlin should definitely be included here.  What do we need beyond the election? We need as much partnership, as much personal contact as possible, especially with the people who are now under pressure there.  So dialogue on our values, on the basis of our European foundations.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The High Representative! The president and dictator Aleksandr Lukashenko has been disarming Belarus for 26 years – a regime based on abuses of power, lies and violations of human rights and freedoms. Belarus is the only European country that still applies the death penalty. The situation is getting worse and worse. The pressure is hardening. People who protest are arrested and imprisoned. Now the regime is threatening to deploy weapons against people who demand what should be self-evident in Europe 2020: the right to free elections.  On Monday, Together with several of my colleagues in this House, I sent a call to the EU's top leadership. What Lukashenko is doing should be punished, not rewarded. We therefore call for the sanctions lifted in 2016 to be reinstated. Belarus is a blot on Europe's democratic map. It wouldn't have to be like that. The presidential elections in August and the growing discontent give us a unique opportunity to condemn Lukashenko and demand democratic elections. Anyone who has been deprived of their freedom for political reasons must be released today. The time for the EU to support democratic development in Belarus is now.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Mr President, Vice-President Borrell, yesterday, in this hemicycle, the German Chancellor, Mrs Angela Merkel, was telling us that among our priorities must remain the defence of Europe's fundamental values. Fundamental rights are a value for which we cannot negotiate anything and it is unacceptable that we, in Europe, have a dictator who is imprisoning exactly the citizens who defend and fight for the same values that we are defending. That is why it is absolutely necessary, High Representative, to act firmly to sanction this regime which persecutes people who believe in democracy, in freedom, in the rule of law. We need to take better care of Belarus, because the Europeans there also deserve another fate.

name: Juozas OLEKAS
text: – Mr President, mr President, I would like to – (DE) Mr President, honourable colleagues, 2020 will be remembered as a year of extraordinary change, the year of COVID-19. However, in the subject that we are debating now, the political situation in Belarus is unfortunately not visible. Lukashenko, who is in office for the sixth time, has once again roughly eliminated all potential rivals before the election. And images from peaceful rallies, demonstrations again ended with the appearance of force structures, beating people and imprisoning them. The European Union must therefore continue to impose and strengthen targeted sanctions on structures and persons involved in the repression of peaceful people. However, one thing cannot be done. It is not possible to restrict contact from ordinary people. The European Union must do the opposite. To facilitate the entry of Belarusians to the countries of the European Union, especially for scientific and cultural purposes, because only direct contacts for ordinary Belarusians show a different possible model of state and the fact that the European Union will not forget them.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, because I will speak in my language, Spanish, so that I can express myself in a more sincere and fluid way. I think putting together three debates on such important issues disfigures the debate a little bit, because one takes attention away from the other. Only the report on human rights and democracy in the world would require a monographic debate, because the importance of this report is enormous, although of course it is no philosopher's stone that solves problems with its simple reading. But this report is more important than ever, and it is also important that we are aware that, apart from explaining what is happening— and many have said it — we must act on it. And that is why we have adopted a new action plan that will cover the period of the next four years, to try to make our activity not only rapporteur, explaining what happens, but of corrective, trying to influence events. We have a special envoy for human rights, who will play a very important role in the implementation of this plan. I understand all the limitations you have and I regret that some of you have diverted the debate on the objective of the report to what is happening within the European Union, which was not the subject of this report or this debate. Some concrete references have been made, for example, to our participation in the generation of a legally binding United Nations instrument in defence of human rights. Unfortunately, we do not have a mandate from the Council to participate in the development of this instrument. We consider it absolutely necessary and participate in consultations in an informal manner, such as the one that took place recently in May in Ecuador, and we will attend next in October. We continue to defend the need for this instrument, but unfortunately we do not have a mandate from the Council to participate in these negotiations. We have decided to renew the mandate of the special envoy to defend religious freedom, who will work in close contact with our special envoy for human rights, Mr Gilmore, and this is undoubtedly one of our priorities for the defence of human rights: religious freedom, which is threatened in many parts of the world and which in some cases affects European citizens and, in any case, affects many who profess the Christian religion. On the facilitation of visas to human rights defenders, which has been raised as an absolutely relevant issue, all I can tell you is that visas are not given by the European Union, given by the Member States; that our delegations in the territory are directly involved trying to get them granted. Yes, yes, visas are not given by the European Union, visas are given by the Member States, if they want to give them. And what we are doing from our delegations is to permanently contact the embassies of the Member States with human rights defenders who are at risk, to facilitate the provision of visas by Member States. I will investigate the response you tell me you have received from the Commission to see on what terms it has been expressed and to what extent it is consistent with our willingness to support human rights defenders as much as we can. Mr President, I would love to be able to extend myself on all the issues that this report raises. It is clear that I cannot do so, and I will move on to the next subject of our debate today, not without pointing out, not without making it clear that the issue of the defence of human rights and democracy in the world is an issue of virtually ineligible extension and depth. Because we are seeing a regression in respect for human rights and democratic practices. We are seeing a rebirth of authoritarianism or new autocrats in many parts of the world, sometimes in a democratic guise, which formally adopt democratic ways and procedures, but which, in essence, are not. And so I think it is essential that we continue to do what we do and do more with the support and help of parliamentarians. And that is why I believe that this report would have deserved a monographic debate. On the situation with Turkey, ladies and gentlemen, I understand the reasons put forward by many of you. But on this Hemiicle, today, a somewhat bellicose dimension has flown, almost at some point I had seemed to see Pope Pius V resurfaced calling the Holy Alliance against Turkey and mobilizing christianity's fleets to deal with the Ottoman invasion. I have no vocation from Chamberlain or Daladier, but neither do I have Don Juan's Austria. If you're looking for a John of Austria, don't look at me, because that belongs to another time in history. We're not looking for confrontation, we're looking to avoid it. And that is why I have expressed myself, on several occasions — the recent one, in Turkey itself, in Ankara — in the terms at the same time firm in defending the territorial integrity and rights of countries that are affected by activities, which we consider illegal, of Turkey in the field of hydrocarbon exploration, but at the same time pointing out that we are not going to change geography and that we need to have a constructive relationship with Turkey. And that this means avoiding an escalation of tension, which has unfortunately manifested itself in incidents, including naval ones, between warships from European and Turkish countries— all members of the same military alliance: NATO — and which are being investigated within the one who must do so— which is NATO itself— but which we must try to prevent them from reproducing.  I insist: here it is not a question of seeking a holy alliance against a new Ottoman invasion, as many of you seemed to propose, but, in more constructive terms, in the face of a complex reality, as some of the participants have also said — Sánchez Amor, Mrs Zovko - that we seek a process that encompasses a negotiation on all the issues that are now conflicting in the relationship between the European Union and some Member States and Turkey , because we have many problems to solve and we also need to do so. And I believe that this can only be achieved from negotiation and dialogue, firmly, but also by avoiding an escalation of tension, which I do not think will lead to solving the problem, but to aggravate it.  And that is what I am trying to do and what I will continue to try to do, with the support of my colleagues in the Foreign Affairs Council, that next Monday will have the issue of Turkey on your agenda. And precisely to prepare for this debate, I have travelled to Greece and Cyprus and also to Turkey.  And on the subject of Belarus, Mr President, I can only agree with the interventions that have been made.  We have pointed out, from the beginning of the electoral process, the number of circumstances that concern us and which we reject about repression and violation of human rights by the Belarusian authorities, and we have issued serious warning messages — they have a list of this, about what we have said, through the formal position procedures of the European Union. But at the same time we also have to maintain contact with civil society and we need to maintain contact with Belarus that allows us to act on reality and improve the situation of the citizens of Belarus with regard to the relationship with the European Union. And both are not incompatible.  It is not incompatible to defend and express our commitment to the civil rights of the citizens of Belarus, the independence and sovereignty of the country and, at the same time, to participate in contacts with civil society and to maintain open communication links.  Something similar might say about Russia. Many of you have referred to the question of why we continue to finance Turkey with pre-accession funds.  Well, you should know that, since 2017, pre-accession funds have been cut, reduced, by EUR 1.3 billion, and that the current allocation is only devoted to working in the areas of democracy, the development of the rule of law, human rights and support for civil society, along with an allocation of 160 million for rural development... no, sorry, 18 million for rural development.  But there are currently no pre-accession funds allocated to the economic areas, because these funds have been, as I say, sharply diminished as a result of Turkey's actions, which the Council has considered to be not compatible with that candidate country status which you have mentioned so many times.  Therefore, we have used the instruments we have, but do not mix everything. Do not mix pre-accession funds with the funds we allocate to support exiles— so to be called 'exiles', without 'migrants'—Syrians who are in Turkey.  Three and a half million people undoubtedly place a significant burden on the host country, and for us to spend money helping this reception by providing schools, providing health care, facilitating education, what's wrong with that? How are we going to stop doing that? We have to keep doing it.  It has recently been decided — and Parliament is there to allocate 500 million more support to Syrian refugees. That's not money for Turkey, as some have said. No, that money is going directly to help, via NGOs working in the united Nations agencies, to the desperate situation of Syrian exiles.  They can't criticize that; they can't say it's some kind of evil exchange with Turkey. It is an absolute need for us to contribute to the maintenance of the effort to help these people, as we do in Jordan and Lebanon. Exactly the same.  With Belarus, the situation, I share your concern, is and may be even more serious. And it is true that there we have limited instruments of action. I can assure you that we have used all those within our reach and that, depending on how events unfold, the Foreign Affairs Council will deal with the matter and take appropriate action.  But on this third item on the agenda, I do wish to express my absolute agreement with the honourable Members when they have expressed themselves, in the terms on which they have done so, on the situation in Belarus.  Ladies and gentlemen... Thank you very much, Mr President, for your generosity over time. And I would have liked to have had more, but I think it was the synthetic response to the many speeches you have made on three issues of the utmost importance.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The joint debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: Writing. – Achieving orderly stable conditions in the Mediterranean is an essential necessity in view of the continuing refugee pressure on the main countries in the north. If this fails, social dislocations will increase in the host countries, which will eventually destroy the EU. The Commission believes that the implementation of the EU-Turkey migration agreement has done a great deal to deal with the refugee problem. In reality, this gag treaty, with which the EU unconditionally surrenders itself to the whims and demands of Turkey, is a bad joke, because from 2015-2019, despite everything, more than 1.21 million cases of illegal border crossings were registered at the EU's eastern external borders. Between 2016 and 2019, more than 25,000 migrants from Turkish reception camps were resettled in the EU. This means that, under the 1:1 rule of the agreement, the same number of illegal immigrants should have been deported back to Turkey during the same period. In fact, there were only 1 954 people! The EU is very good at concealing its own inability to deal with it, but an absolute failure to solve the most elementary problems. And so the existing pull effect will drive further legions of people across the Mediterranean to us. It could also be different: cancellation of the EU-Turkey agreement and the introduction of consistent measures following the successful Australian model - "You will not make Europe home!"

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. The issue of stability and security in the Mediterranean is closely linked to the conflicts in Libya and Syria, which have a significant impact in terms of uncontrolled migration and terrorism. Turkey is playing a leading role in both cases. We have strongly condemned the Turkish Government's military operation in north-eastern Syria and interference in Libya's internal affairs, where the UN embargo is being violated, and have frustrated efforts to find a political solution. Turkey, despite being considered an important trading partner, a NATO ally and a candidate country to become a member of the EU, in the Aegean area, has severely deteriorated relations with Greece and has repeatedly shown that it pursues interests that are not in line with the principles, values and sovereign rights of EU states. If there is a European will to find solutions to instability in the Mediterranean, we need to find instruments as soon as possible to reverse the negative trend in our relations with the Turkish authorities. This is also a fundamental issue for the security of European territory, to be protected without allowing discounts to anyone.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – The annual report on the human rights situation in the world is again disappointing, as the chapter on national minorities completely ignores very incomplete and serious problems, such as the disenfranchiseing of Hungarians in Transcarpathia. At the same time, thanks to the tenacious work of some Members, particular attention has been paid to discrimination against religious minorities in the human rights report, including the persecution of Christians in the world. This gives rise to moderate confidence that, after all these years of silence, the European institutions are finally addressing the situation of Christians, since Christianity is currently the most sent religion in the world. Unfortunately, we are still a long way from putting proper pressure on governments that violate religious freedom on a daily basis. Nevertheless, my like-minded colleagues and I work every day to ensure that the EU stands firmly in favour of the protection of Christians in the world. The protection of Christians and the support of Christian communities must be a matter of honour for us.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. – It should be assessed as a meaningful step forward that discrimination and persecution of religious minorities will be given special attention in the 2019 Human Rights Report. It is also thanks to the years of work of many of my colleagues in the European Parliament that we have come this far. However, there are many differences between meaning and reality. It is years of experience that the EU does not put pressure on governments that violate religious freedom every day. Therefore, repressive regimes simply take this EU approach as consent. In other words, as a result of the Union's silence, they are free to continue their infringements, including against religious minorities. Europe must therefore be firm and consistent. What should I do? EU diplomacy should speak out each time to protect the persecuted, both in bilateral relations and in multilateral for a. It is not primarily a religious issue for Europe to act in defence of persecuted Christians. Communities suffering persecution, in particular their persecuted ones, in all parts of the world simply see Europe as their possible primary helper, the centre of the Christian world, the bearer of Christian heritage. I can assure you that, as co-chair of the interfaith working group of the PP group, I will be a partner of the European Commission in the fight for religious freedom. If, on the other hand, Europe, driven by extreme secularism, is silent on religious discrimination, persecution or genocide, one of the most serious human rights violations, it is complicity in the deaths of millions of victims worldwide.

name: Elena KOUNTOURA
text: Writing. – fifteen years have passed since the start of negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union; It continues to violate the sovereign rights of its neighbours, strengthening stability in the region. It continues to despise international law and the law of the sea, as it repeatedly does in the case of the Greek and Cypriot EEZs. Turkey's President, Mr Erdogan, has no hesitate to dangerously escalate the situation in the region with illegal demarcation agreements, illegal drilling and repeated violations of European airspace. In the last six months alone, Mr. Borrell, Turkey has committed 3,000 violations of Greek airspace. President Erdogan unilaterally challenges international treaties, such as the Treaty of Lausanne. It tools monuments of world cultural heritage, as it does in Hagia Sophia, provoking the religious feeling of Christians worldwide. It exploits the pain of refugees to create a crisis at European borders and continues to systematically violate human rights and the rule of law. Mr Borrell, we have heard nothing about sanctions against this anti-European policy, but we have heard generalities about solidarity, dialogue and negotiations with a country that insists on not complying with the values, principles and law of the European Union.

name: Ondřej KOVAŘÍK
text: in writing. – The recent developments in Belarus ahead of the August presidential election are increasingly worrying. Arbitrary detentions and maltreatment of opposition candidates, civic activists as well as peaceful protesters are totally unacceptable and have no place in Europe in the 21st century. Nobody should be deprived of their fundamental rights and political freedoms such as freedom of expression and assembly or the right to free and fair elections, including the right to register as an election candidate. The European Parliament as well as the European Commission have repeatedly voiced their concerns about the deteriorating situation in Belarus. The EU expects Belarusian authorities to immediately stop arbitrary arrests and restrictions and to uphold their international commitments to respect human rights and fundamental freedoms of its citizens. It’s first and foremost the citizens of Belarus who should decide about the future of their country and it’s a good sign that they are ready to participate in the election process. Belarusian authorities are now facing an important choice. Free, fair and peaceful election will be decisive for the future of Belarus as well as for its future dialogue with the EU. In these turbulent times, Belarus can’t afford another missed opportunity.

name: Janina OCHOJSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – At the beginning, I regret to point out that I have not seen any improvement in the human rights situation. On the contrary, I am receiving many signals from different parts of the world from many backgrounds that the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic has worsened the situation and human rights violations have increased worldwide, including in the European Union. Particular attention should be paid to climate change, which poses a direct and far-reaching threat to people, in particular to indigenous peoples and communities around the world. It is well known that the effects of climate change are inextricably linked to human rights enforcement.  From information provided by international and non-governmental organisations, we learn about the dramatic situation of migrants, who are often left alone, experience aggression, violence and do not receive basic assistance. Many citizens and human rights defenders under the guise of fighting COVID-19 are subject to government scrutiny and surveillance. I consider such situations unacceptable.  At this point, I would like to stress that the M.IN is based on values such as human rights. I therefore encourage and call for human rights to be entedied into any EU policy.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. – Confidence in EU-Turkey relations has been permanently lost under the sole responsibility of the Turkish side. Today, President Erdogan continues to accuse the EU of having received nothing for refugees, when we are well aware that almost EUR 6 billion has been disbursed. European funds for this purpose to Turkey. The incitement of the hybrid attack of thousands of migrants in Evros last March, the illegal drilling in Ann. Mediterranean, the continuous violation of the sovereign rights of Greece and Cyprus, the signing of the unsubstantiated Turkish-Libyan Memorandum, the questioning of the Treaty of Lausanne, the threats to the EU, the violation of the universal character of Hagia Sophia are part of a deliberate policy of Turkey, which strengthens any attempt at dialogue. There is no common ground for cooperation with Turkey, and communication bridges have been torn down. We are in a position of strength and we must prove decisively as a Union that we can implement all sanctioning measures against the Turkish side. We cannot continue to allow Turkey to threaten us, while you, Mr Borrell, High Representative of the EU, instead of transferring to Ankara the climate in Brussels and the need for Turkey to refrain from any aggressive action, appear as a neutral mediator in Greek-Turkish relations.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The next item on the agenda is the second round of voting. The dossiers on which we are now voting can be found on the agenda. Before we begin, I would like to give the floor to Mr Gussao, who has asked to comment on his report on the guidelines for member employment policies in accordance with Rule 159(4) of the Rules of Procedure.
