name: José GUSMÃO
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, the Covid-19 crisis has been a crisis with very serious public health implications, but it also has, and we have already begun to feel them, dramatic consequences from an economic and social point of view, and therefore the report of the guidelines for employment policies this year is a report with a particular responsibility, because it aims to start , from now on, responding to an economic and social crisis that is already being felt and which we know will worsen over the coming months.  And that is why it is so important that, knowing that there are important differences between the various political groups with regard to the functioning of the labour market, with regard to public services, economic policies, have achieved a consensus, such a broad and broad majority, to support a set of policies that are fundamental , to protect the employment of those who have it and also to protect public services and social policies for those who do not have, or will lose, employment during this economic and social crisis.  And, therefore, I would like to thank the work that has been done by all the rapporteurs of this report, for the spirit of commitment that has made this text possible, which has already had very important support from the European Confederation of Trade Unions and which will, I think, be a very important contribution from the European Parliament to fulfil the strategic plan that has often been affirmed in this plenary to respond to this crisis , to respond in the most energetic and inclusive way we are capable of, leaving no one behind. That is the spirit that, I think, moved all the rapporteurs who supported this report.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the sustainability strategy for chemicals by Maria Spyraki, Maria Arena, Frédérique Ries, Sven Giegold, Danilo Oscar Lancini, Pietro Fiocchi, Anja Hazekamp on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000044/2020 – B9-0013/2020) (2020/2531(RSP)).

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: author. – Madam President, with this motion for a resolution, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to proceed with the chemicals strategy for sustainability. Chemicals are everywhere. They are in our food, in our water, in our clothes and in our cosmetics. They are in the air that we breathe. In other words, they affect all aspects of our daily life. Our first priority is to upgrade the level of protection of the consumer and the environment. For this reason, we are asking for the elimination of risk-hazardous substances and substitutions to safer alternatives when it’s feasible. We call on the Commission to take into account the risk posed by endocrine disrupters and the combination effect of different chemicals. Commissioner, we are focusing on a very ambitious target by aiming to set the chemical safety standard for the entire world. The European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) should support the EU’s international trade policy by defining provisions and fostering regulatory systems built upon EU standards for chemical safety. This would enhance protection beyond the EU borders and extend the level playing field. Chemicals are also the industry of industries. A size—based grouping approach will enable the industry, in complementarity with the ‘one substance, one assessment’ principle. This strategy must also grant sufficient time for the industry’s manufacturers in order to deliver safe and performing products and incentivise the EU industrial production and economy. In this regard, the strategy should secure adequate funding to accelerate the development of innovative and safe alternatives. The strategy should also ensure that unnecessary animal tests are avoided, incentivising the development of smart testing strategies and artificial intelligence methods. However, everything is not dependent on this House. Everything is not dependent on Brussels and on Brussels’ political will. That’s why we also have to increase the level of implementation of the existing EU legislation on chemicals, asking the Member States to fully implement the current legislative framework in order to provide a safe and sustainable environment as well as a competitive European market. In this strategy, we have three critical allies – the three agencies: ECHA, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and the European Medicines Agency (EMA). Firstly we must avoid overlap between these three agencies. Secondly, we have to secure their adequate funding by providing additional resources. I would like to conclude with the need for the chemicals strategy for sustainability to be aligned with the two main aspects of the Green Deal. The first one is green and the second is digital. In this regard, we fully support  ECHA’s initiative to promote the establishment of a fully-connected and interoperable EU chemical safety database platform to facilitate the seamless sharing of data between authorities and to provide public access to researchers, regulators, industry and the citizens at large. Κυρίες και κύριοι συνάδελφοι, Επίτροπε, κυρία Πρόεδρε, η στρατηγική για τα βιώσιμα χημικά μπορεί να οδηγήσει τη γενιά μας και τα παιδιά μας σε ένα μέλλον με λιγότερα προβλήματα. Μπορεί να οδηγήσει τη βιομηχανία σε βιώσιμες λύσεις με πολύ χαμηλότερες επιπτώσεις στο περιβάλλον. Αρκεί τα χημικά προϊόντα που εισάγονται από τρίτες χώρες στην Ευρωπαϊκή Ένωση να έχουν ακριβώς τις ίδιες προδιαγραφές με αυτά που παρασκευάζονται και καταναλώνονται στην Ευρωπαϊκή Ένωση. Η αγορά είναι παγκόσμια και το στοίχημα για τα βιώσιμα χημικά αφορά τον πλανήτη, αφορά τη ζωή μας.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, today’s debate and the resolution you will adopt tomorrow on the upcoming chemical strategy for sustainability come very timely and I would like to thank you for the opportunity to reply today to the issues you raise in your oral question and to give you a brief update on where we are with this strategy.  As announced in the Commission’s Work Programme for 2020 – we have updated recently to respond to the corona pandemic – the chemical strategy is planned for the third quarter and we are currently working towards an adoption at the end of the third quarter this year. Internal discussions and preparatory work are still ongoing, so I’m sure you will understand that the information I can provide today remains general and that I cannot yet go into any details of the upcoming strategy.  The chemical strategy for sustainability is one of the key deliverables of the Green Deal and one of the priorities, of course, within my portfolio this year. When we adopted the Green Deal last December we all agreed to ensure a toxic-free environment. The strategy had a twofold objective. First, it should help to protect citizens and the environment better against hazardous chemicals and it had to encourage innovation for the development of safe and sustainable alternatives. This twofold objective has guided our internal preparatory work from the very beginning and has also made it clear from the very start that to better combine health and environmental protection, and increase global competitiveness, all parties and stakeholders have to work closely together.  This also applies, of course, to the Commission, which is why my services, my team and I are preparing the strategy in a very close cooperation with many other DGs, Cabinets and Commissioners involved in this very horizontal, I would say, topic.  I appreciate that in the resolution that you will adopt tomorrow you equally acknowledge this horizontal character of chemicals. You highlight both the need to act towards a safe and sustainable use of chemicals, but also the essential role of the chemical sector in reaching the multiple targets of the Green Deal, such as the zero-pollution ambition, climate neutrality, energy transition, the promotion of energy efficiency and the circular economy.  Let me already thank you for the considerable work and effort you have put into this important resolution which, as I said, comes very timely. Once adopted, we will examine it very carefully and take it into account when finalising our chemical strategy over the next weeks. We will, of course, also take into account the over 400 comments and contributions we received from stakeholders and citizens on the roadmap for the chemical strategy, which was published for feedback from 9 May until 20 June of this year.  Let me now provide you with some more elements on our upcoming chemical strategy for sustainability. The strategy is based and will build on a number of policy evaluations and previous initiatives linked to the EU chemicals legislation and in particular the second REACH review from 2018, the fitness check of chemicals legislation from 2019, the Communication on endocrine disrupters from 2018 and the Communication on options to address the interface between chemical, product and waste legislation from 2018.  To reach our main objective, the strategy will particularly focus on the following five elements. First: strengthening legislation for higher health and environmental protection from hazardous chemicals. Despite the great achievements of EU chemicals legislation, we urgently need to step up action, in particular to better protect vulnerable groups, to address the combined effects of chemicals, to tackle endocrine disrupters and persistent substances. Second: boosting innovation and competitiveness. We need to incentivise the development of safe and sustainable production and use of chemicals. The transition to ‘safe and sustainable by design’ represents a major opportunity for the EU’s innovation and competitiveness. At the same time, a strong and sustainable EU industry is an important asset for the EU to contribute to global sustainability. We also need to support the recovery from the economic crisis, build resilience and ensure strategic autonomy in the supply of essential chemicals in Europe, for instance for health applications or technologies critical to achieve climate neutrality, digital transition, clean and safe material cycles and zero pollution.  Third: streamlining the existing framework. Our legislative framework is overall fit for purpose, but also complex, and in some cases inconsistent and slow. This is a challenge for both stakeholders and authorities. We have the opportunity to rationalise and simplify and make it more effective, including by moving towards a ‘one substance – one assessment’ process. Insufficient enforcement and poor compliance are also major bottlenecks, preventing existing legislation from attaining its full potential.  Fourth: intensifying research and knowledge on the impacts of chemicals on health and the environment, but also ways to better process and share this data and information for regulatory use, but also for consumer information or industrial use in the supply chain. One key area is the tracking of hazardous substances in articles to achieve non-toxic material cycles and ultimately a circular economy.  Finally, strengthening the global dimension. It is important that the EU becomes more and more an example worldwide of standards on sound management of chemicals to strengthen international standards and support third countries in the safe production and use of chemicals.  Once the final chemical strategy for sustainability has been adopted by the College, I will, of course, be happy to come back and present it to you and I already look forward to working very closely with you to implement it, because the work will, of course, not finish with the adoption of the strategy, quite the contrary. For now, let me thank you for your attention and I look forward to the views of the political groups.

name: Pernille WEISS
text: ppe group. Madam President! The climate and the environment will soon be no longer available! At the same time, the world's population is growing, there are more mouths to be saturated. Here too, the European Union has a very special task as a 'first mover' for sustainable plant protection products. In fact, the Commission itself mentioned this when you made your proposal for a European Green Pact last year, and we in the PPE Group have not forgotten that. That is why we are now giving you a resolution in which we invite you to present a chemistry strategy for sustainability as soon as possible. One of the main ingredients of this is to make the fast-track registration of low-risk pesticides a real fast-track. There's no point in it being just in the name. European companies are inventing more and more sustainable plant protection products for the benefit of the environment and public health in these years, but registration, it is lagging, and thus the new, environmentally friendly solutions do not reach farmers, either in Europe or in the rest of the world, and that is simply not working! Now turn the fast-track into a true fast-track! We owe this to the planet and to the mouths that need to be saturated, but also to our innovative farmers, who often get on the back foot for causing the stressful conditions of the environment. That is not fair, nor is it sensible!

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of President, in its communication on the Green Pact for Europe, the Commission announced its 'zero pollution' ambition for a toxic substance-free environment. In this context, reducing exposure to hazardous chemicals is of course a major issue and all the laws regulating chemicals must be the bulwark for citizens and the environment, in the face of the major risk posed by some of these substances. Through our resolution, Parliament is sending a clear and ambitious message, first of all for the full implementation of existing legislation, but also for an evolution of legislation on many aspects. Strong measures for health and the environment are needed and we must take responsibility for this. We want health to come before the economic interests of certain industries. What is sustainable chemistry? Specific criteria must be adopted to define it, otherwise sustainable chemistry will only be a concept that industries will use to "greenwash" their activities, to the detriment of the health of citizens. A more sustainable chemistry is not a chemistry that provides ever more revenue to shareholders of the chemical industry, it is a chemistry that fully integrates the objectives of public health and safeguarding biodiversity. This is primarily through reducing the dangers associated with chemicals, by replacing the most dangerous substances with safe alternatives, by increasing transparency in the authorisation process, which also incorporates social and environmental costs, especially for persistent chemicals. The cost of the chemical industry today in relation to health is 160 billion euros per year. If these costs were borne by the industry, I can assure you that replacement with alternative substances would go much faster. So that's where we need to go.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, our resolution sets you a course today: the course for the sustainable strategy for chemicals, which the Commission will therefore present to us - to listen to you - before the end of the year, with a goal that we share, of course, that of strengthening the protection of the health of citizens and the environment, a goal which is ambitious and 71% of chemicals manufactured in the European Union are classified as hazardous. So the Commission - because we have benefited from some leaks - wants to strengthen the regulatory framework, that is good news. It aims at REACH, of course, in particular, with a group approach for similar substances in order to speed up the risk assessment by our European Chemicals Agency. One small thing in this regard: this logic by family must also apply to the procedure of restriction for dangerous substances, phthalates, to name but one example, prohibited in children's toys, allowed elsewhere. We are also being considered by the Commission to see new criteria for risk management. European legislation must, of course, protect against endocrine disruptors, from neurotoxics. I am thinking here of the many workers who are exposed to solvents or heavy metals on a daily basis. Finally, it is essential to take action against PFAS, these perfluorated compounds found in foams, in Teflon stoves, not to mention them, in food packaging. PFAS, because mobile, because persistent, very persistent, are a real danger to our health. The European Union must move forward, Commissioner, with a phasing out of this class of almost 5,000 chemicals. I note, and I conclude here, that last December the Dutch Government pushed the issue, the debate, in the Council. The window of opportunity exists, so we must seize it.

name: Isabella TOVAGLIERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I actually see a number of critical issues in this strategy, starting with the excessively ideological approach. Indeed, if we want concrete results for the environment, we certainly cannot demonise a sector such as chemistry – excellence at European and Italian level and, above all, an already advanced sector in the field of sustainability – burdening it with additional unsustainable burdens. Without a pragmatic approach, we risk hitting European chemistry and then finding ourselves importing the same products from outside Europe, precisely where the standards we impose are not guaranteed. It is therefore a out-of-the-way attitude that is harmful to workers and our businesses. Let us not forget the importance of the relocation of chemical companies and their productions to Europe, an objective to be pursued, certainly not by imposing fake green taxes, put only to cash in, but by means of instruments that favour the sector, bringing back to Europe capacities that we have left abroad. Without pragmatism and balance, therefore, we risk only penalising a strategic sector for the whole of Europe, a sector that should instead be actively supported in its transition to even more sustainable production.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The European Parliament is calling for no less than a paradigm shift in European chemical policy – for our health, a toxic environment and the sustainable transformation of the chemical industry.  The European Commission must have a zero-tolerance strategy against toxic chemicals in the environment. Only this week, Commissioner, new figures were announced in Germany: one in five children – and this is alarming – is heavily burdened by chemicals in everyday objects. The load is so high that one in five children cannot be excluded from long-term damage. In particular, hormone-altering chemicals such as bisphenol A and Co. and eternity chemicals such as PFAS must be banned as a group.  Ambitious chemical policy does not only protect our children. It is also an opportunity for a European industry that does not sleep the future. Clean chemistry in Europe can not only create a clean environment for people and nature, but also stabilise 1.2 million sustainable chemical jobs. Commissioner, we expect an ambitious strategy from you.

name: Pietro FIOCCHI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, as a shadow rapporteur, I’m sorry to say that I am not in agreement with a lot of the compromise amendments. If all the amendments are approved, the regulation will be extremely punishing, especially for the small and micro enterprises. I’m very familiar with this matter, given my 35 years as an entrepreneur with strong experience in the REACH regulation, occupational safety and health, CoP regulation and producer responsibility. There are some extremely problematic points, among which the juridical nightmare of a regulation that wants to change another regulation like the CoP and occupational safety – this is an extremely complex and expensive burden on the effects of combined or multiple chemicals which is very difficult to handle. The introduction of the concept of ‘no data, no market’ is very dangerous for a lot of smaller companies and the impossibility of finding better alternatives to banned substances in a short time. I’m a strong believer in the concept of banning dangerous substances, but the direction this regulation has taken will create massive competitive disadvantages for all EU companies, especially the small ones. Again, the focus is on the companies which are already heavily regulated, and nothing is said about what comes out of private homes.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I would say to the Commissioner that it is our right to have a non—toxic environment, but we are sadly miles away from that. Still, workers in the EU and the rest of the world are dying at an age much too young, only because of the dangerous chemicals they were exposed to simply by turning up at work. Still, pollinators, one of the most essential links in our ecosystem, are dying because of the dangerous pesticides we are spraying on our fields. Still, babies are exposed to endocrine—disrupting chemicals just by playing with the toxic toys we let them play with. And still, millions of animals are suffering horribly in laboratories as a result of outdated and cheap practices they even dare to call science.  Even though the EU has some decent legislation in place to protect its citizens against exposure to the most dangerous and hazardous chemicals, those chemicals are still exported to other parts of the world. I am glad that the Commissioner has promised us a zero—pollution ambition for a toxic—free environment. With this resolution, the European Parliament is giving the Commission some homework: to ensure that the Chemical strategy for sustainability lives up to our expectations. We have no time to waste. I urge you, Commissioner, to deliver the toxic—free world we all desperately need and deserve.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Members for their interventions and for the important points they raised, many of which are also reflected in the resolution they will adopt tomorrow. I take very good note of these points and the views expressed and we will duly consider them when finalising the strategy over the next weeks. My objective with this strategy is very clear: it’s to set out a vision for a comprehensive framework and a very concrete roadmap for action, where all parties should work together. The COVID-19 crisis has clearly increased the urgency to step up action in the chemicals area. We have to ensure the protection of our citizens, support the socio-economic recovery of European industry and also promote our strategic autonomy for those chemicals which are important to society and health. This strategy will be delivered as the very first step towards a zero—pollution ambition for a toxic-free environment, with the action plan to follow in 2021. It will also complement other objectives under the Green Deal, notably to protect biodiversity and to move towards climate neutrality – at the end of the day, a huge contribution to a circular economy. The strategy will also support other priorities of the European Commission, such as the digital transition strengthening the European Union’s competitiveness, fighting cancer, and many others. Its horizontal character makes it so relevant, and we will need joint efforts and the constructive involvement of all stakeholders to implement it and make it a success on the ground. I am counting on your support in this regard and I look forward to continuing the close cooperation with you on this important policy.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: A motion for a resolution has been tabled in accordance with Rule 136(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place today, Thursday 9 July 2020, and the final vote will take place tomorrow, Friday, 10 July 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Johan DANIELSSON
text: Written. "There is no doubt that a chemical strategy for sustainability is needed. Today, workers die completely needlessly from avoidable work-related cancers. That is totally unacceptable. People should never die from their jobs. It is correct that the resolution on the chemicals strategy mentions health and safety aspects, but that is far from enough. The Commission needs to include a zero vision for work-related cancer in the strategy. In addition, work should be made towards an ambitious revision of the Directive on carcinogens and mutagenic substances (CMDs) and binding occupational exposure limits for 25 additional priority carcinogens under the CMD by 2024. Furthermore, the Commission should also ensure that chemicals contained in products or used in the work must be risk assessed together with trade union representatives and accounted for in an easily accessible manner for workers. In order to protect the health and safety of workers, they should be given a regular review of the management of chemicals on a regular basis. It's really pretty obvious. Objective must be a good and healthy working environment for everyone who works. A poor working environment must never be a competitive advantage. Here, europe must take the lead and ensure that companies that put workers at risk of life do not escape.

name: Rovana PLUMB
text: in writing. – I support this resolution because it is necessary, at EU level, to have a strategy to promote sustainability in the field of chemicals, on the basis of which to review legislation, which is essential to set direction for innovation for the transition to a safe and sustainable chemicals sector, and long-term investments to achieve an environment free of toxic substances must be appropriately sized. The new strategy should be consistent with the other policy objectives of the Green Pact and complement them, in particular with the objectives of the Climate Act, the Circular Economy Action Plan, the new industrial strategy for Europe and the European Cancer Control Plan, as well as the new situation of the European economy after the COFID-19 pandemic. Also, in order to promote sustainability in this area, we need to support the involvement of all stakeholders so that no one is left behind.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the council and Commission declarations on strengthening the process of Roma integration in Europe over the next ten years (2020/2692(RSP)). I would point out to Members that there are no spontaneous speeches during the debate and that no blue cards are accepted.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. When we talk today about the social situation of the Roma, we are talking about ten to twelve million people in Europe, then we are talking about about six million citizens of the European Union. Many, too many of them live in extreme poverty and are exposed to unimaginable hardships. It is almost ten years since we agreed on the Roma strategy. Some of you were already involved when the process was launched in 2011 with the great support of this Parliament. Almost ten years have passed since then and, unfortunately, we have to say that the results we have achieved so far are disappointing.  This is also reported by the Commission, and you, honourable Members, also emphasise this in its resolution last year. We have had to recognise that it takes too long to eradicate the great intergenerational poverty and to end the decades, if not centuries, of marginalisation of Gypsies. I say this also as a representative of a country that, decades ago, fell victim to fascism with around 500 000 Gypsies, innocent men, women and children. Yes, the road to full equality, inclusion and Roma participation is long. Yes, we should have already achieved more, and yes, there is no doubt that we can and must make much more effort in the future. But there is also good news. As reported by the European Commission, the greatest progress has been made in the field of education. For example, Member States are taking measures to ensure that fewer Roma children leave school early and that more Roma children have access to early childhood education and compulsory education. This is, of course, crucial. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In the 21st century, discrimination, racist prejudice and hatred must be a thing of the past. Discrimination and anti-Gypsyism must be eradicated once and for all if we want to look ourselves in the eye and if we ourselves want to be perceived as a just and equal society.  But we also need a consistent political strategy to combat social inequality. Extreme poverty over several generations inevitably leads to an accumulation of serious disadvantages in health, education, housing and work. We finally need a concept that will look at all these areas at the same time. This is the only way to break the cycle of marginalisation. And, of course, representatives of the Roma must also be involved in this process. But not somewhere on the sidelines, but on an equal footing, in a dialogue of respect, without prejudice. If someone does not have access to health care or a mainstream school, if someone does not have a decent home or a job, how can that person ever realize his dreams? How can this person ever develop his talents in our society?  The health issue in times of the Corona pandemic weighs particularly heavily. Roma, like everyone else, must have equal access to basic health care and specialised health services. With regard to the new initiatives announced by our Commission for October, I would like to thank you, the European Parliament, for putting this issue on the agenda time and again. In doing so, you not only helped to launch the ten-year strategic framework back then, in 2011, but you have also regularly reminded us in recent years that this issue remains urgent. Honourable Members, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for her excellent work. Imagine a Roma child born in the year when the framework for the Roma strategy was first adopted, namely 2011, a year of hope, grand plans and brilliant promises for the Gypsy community.  Today, this child is nine years old. Unfortunately, it is likely that it has not been given the opportunities that most of us here take for granted, which we want for our children and for our granddaughters. Extreme poverty, racial discrimination and social exclusion are not just keywords, they are the sad reality in the middle of Europe, in the midst of us in all the Member States of the European Union.  They are made up of unfair obstacles that deprive many Roma of any chance of a decent life. So let us think of this one now nine-year-old child. Let us think of the six million citizens of the European Union, adults and children, girls and boys, women and men. What prospects will they have in the coming years? We must not abandon them.  The Council and the European Parliament are allies in the joint efforts to promote Roma inclusion at European level. I am very confident that this alliance will continue. Member States have the key competences. But we, as the institutions of the European Union, can help to ensure that this arduous and long road leads to a good end. Fortunately, we also have EU legislation prohibiting discrimination against all ethnic minorities, including the Roma. This year is a crucial year for Roma inclusion strategies. I fear that many of this community have heard this phrase too often. So it's about more than paying lip service. It is a question of concrete action. I am very excited, dear Helena Dalli, about the package that the Commission is currently preparing. I assure you that we will do everything in our power to ensure that this package is adopted under our chairmanship. Let us all draw strength from the European values of justice and solidarity for the future. Europe was, is and remains a dream of solidarity, a dream of freedom, dignity and equality, but also – and above all – for the Gypsies, to whom we are paying special tribute today.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank Mr Roth for this heartfelt introduction to this very important debate. Honourable Members, thank you for putting Roma inclusion on today’s agenda. I thank all of you here today, and the honourable Ms Lívia Járóka, Mr Romeo Franz and Mr Peter Pollák in particular, for the visibility that they provide for the Roma community, their commitment and their tireless work for Roma equality, inclusion and participation, including through the organisation of this debate. I equally reiterate my thanks to the Members present here today for the relentless support towards advancing the agenda on Roma inclusion and equality participation. I shall start by quoting Chancellor Merkel in her speech here in this Parliament yesterday. She said, ‘human and civil rights, the inviolability of human dignity, the freedom of individual, personal, political and social development, protection against discrimination and disregard, equality –equality that is not only claimed but also realised. These are the ethical and political foundations on which Europe rests ... These are the rights that apply to everyone. They do not apply to some more and others less. They do not apply to some always and to others only sometimes. They apply. This is the promise of Europe that we must guarantee: that citizens can truly be free to live their religious beliefs, their cultural or political beliefs, that they may adhere to their respective ideas of happiness, or good life.’ With this Chancellor Merkel quote in our minds and in our hearts, I shall now address the Roma reality, the subject of our debate today. As you know, Roma living in marginalised communities are some of the most vulnerable groups hit the hardest by the coronavirus pandemic. The already existing inequalities have been compounded; long—lasting inequalities, discrimination and exclusion have become more visible. The Commission is aware of this fact, not least through a series of targeted communications and we have done all possible to deliver prompt intervention. We will remain on alert and will continue to intervene, based on need, in line with our duty and responsibility. The Commission responded from the very beginning of the outbreak of the crisis. For instance, together with Commissioners Kyriakides and Schmit, I wrote to Member States emphasising the need for specific measures for the most vulnerable groups, including Roma, in the context of the coronavirus crisis. We also put forward several instruments as an immediate response to the crisis, which can offer support to vulnerable groups such as Roma. No one, and definitely not the most vulnerable, should carry more than the fair share of the burden of this epidemic. The Roma community has suffered not just the health and economic impact of this crisis. In some Member States, and I really regret to say, Roma persons have also been portrayed as a public health threat during the crisis. This is shameful. The pandemic brought to the fore and accentuated deep—rooted discrimination and hatred against these communities. The European Commission condemns strongly all forms of stigmatisation, ethnicisation and Roma scapegoating. All of these are contrary to EU values and go against the basic principles of our democracy. The European Union has the legally binding tools to combat discrimination, including those based on racial or ethnic origin. The Council Framework Decision on combating certain forms of racism and xenophobia is the tool to fight against hate crime, including anti—gypsyism, in speech or action. The Racial Equality Directive prohibits discrimination on grounds of racial or ethnic origin in key aspects of life. Roma, as an ethnic minority, fall within the protected categories of people covered by these legal tools, and we have a duty to enforce them. But we also know that legislation is one thing and how effective this is on people’s lives is another. Legislation on its own is never enough, in any area, and thus we must do much more. We are closely monitoring Member States’ compliance with the directive. Three infringement procedures are ongoing against Member States. They relate to the segregation of Roma children in mainstream schools and their over—representation in schools for children with intellectual disabilities. I am actively working with the countries concerned to put an end to this situation, and will not shy away from opening further infringement proceedings where there is the need. Overcoming discrimination and exclusion of Roma requires a long—term commitment and a comprehensive approach. As I had announced, we are preparing an ambitious post—2020 initiative: the ‘strategic EU framework for equality, inclusion and participation of Roma up to 2030’. This will also reflect the new needs emerging from the coronavirus crisis among marginalised Roma communities. I plan to present the new initiative later this year. We aim to have a strong, ambitious and all—encompassing strategy. It is my firm belief that, building on the findings of the evaluation of the 2011-2020 framework, we need to put a stronger focus on promoting equality for Roma by fighting anti—Gypsyism and discrimination, hand in hand with promoting socioeconomic inclusion. We need to better reflect the diversity among Roma; ensure meaningful participation of and partnership with Roma communities, Roma civil society and all other stakeholders; promote a consistent focus on Roma equality and inclusion in all mainstream policies; and work towards improved data collection and monitoring of progress through indicators and clear targets to ensure effective progress and promote policy learning. The dire consequences of this pandemic on Roma communities have further accentuated the need for a renewed and strong commitment from all stakeholders to advance further together with the full involvement of Roma people themselves. Roma people need your and my and our indefatigable, relentless commitment and hard work. I trust that together, we can do a lot to change and improve our societies. Together, we can achieve more: more inclusion, more equality, more justice, more participation for our Roma communities in Europe.

name: Peter POLLÁK
text: for the PPE Group. – Commissioner, it is time to admit that, despite the abundant European financial resources, miserable progress has been made in Roma communities over the last ten years. A new European initiative on Roma inclusion by 2030 will be adopted in October. This initiative needs to place much greater emphasis on the results and effectiveness of the funds spent. We need to see tangible results.  In order to focus on those Member States where, in the absence of political will, macroeconomic problems are occurring and regional disparities are wideling. We must focus on countries with a larger Roma population, where the Roma in the 21st century live in conditions that we know from the African continent, without water supply or sewerage.  Close monitoring and active participation of Roma in decision-making processes must become an essential part of all activities. The Roma are citizens of the European Union, they are an untapped potential, both human and economic. It must be acknowledged that the Roma in Europe also face institutional racism. Unfortunately, there are children among the victims.  Personally, as a Roma, I regret and it was, in fact, really disappointing for me to find out that some of the political factions of the European Parliament that have their mouths full on the human rights agenda have blocked the joint resolution that could have come out of this debate. So when it came to violating the law of African Americans in the United States, they did not hesitate there and adopted a similar resolution. It is precisely inaction and the inability to name things as they are that leads to an increase in extremism and racism, as we are unfortunately witnessing here in Europe.

name: Evin INCIR
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It is clear that too many EU countries do not apply Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union at all times. Roma in Europe have for too long endured severe oppression of all sections of society. It is about discrimination in the labour market. It is about discrimination in the housing market. It is about discrimination in schools and in dialogue with different authorities. It's about young, old and especially women.  The Covid-19 pandemic has clearly exposed and exacerbated the weaknesses in our societies. One of the weaknesses was precisely that the situation of already vulnerable groups became even worse. This applies to vulnerable groups in general and roma in particular. That's enough. Discrimination must be combated and eradicated. In democratic, free and equal societies, there is no room for discrimination. What we have done so far is not enough. I obviously think that strategies are important, but we need measurable targets. We need to move from words to deeds, and we need to move from planning to implementation.

name: Anna Júlia DONÁTH
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, thanks to the Roma policy of the last decade, we have lost generations. In fact, cohesion funds have not reduced the difference between people, but have increased them. The sad reality is that in many European countries the chances of roma children growing up in poverty have been reduced. They are the first to be sacrificed by the political elite when a crisis inges. In fact, this resignation is a loss for all of us. With segregated education and discrimination in the labour market, we are blocking the opportunity for thousands, hundreds of thousands of people, to take on high-value-added jobs. Yes, a cruel attitude towards the Roma makes society as a whole poorer and countries more uncompetitive. They spent money blindly, and they expected that this, and only that, would solve all the problems. All they've forgotten is that catching up can't be based solely on money. True catch-up can only be achieved through a humane and just policy. Therefore, we must implement the support policy for the next decade jointly with the Roma and take responsibility together. The last Hungarian EU Presidency has already presented a Roma strategy. Yet we are here today nine years later because various political forces, such as the Hungarian Prime Minister, can trample on anyone at any time just to get a vote. Now it's gypsy's turn. Cruel treatment of them is becoming a government program before our eyes. We need a just and humane solution with a shared responsibility. Let's not give up on anyone, but let's act together.

name: Annalisa TARDINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 'reception must always take place in accordance with the law and must therefore be combined, when necessary, with the firm repression of abuses'. It is in the words of Pope John Paul II the deepest meaning of the concept of inclusion, understood as a process made up of rights but also by duties. Unfortunately, today the term 'inclusion' has become synonymous with renouncing our values and our way of life, almost as if including the other meant changing oneself. Unfortunately, this is the case with the Roma, who have set up criminal networks in our country, avoiding the census, while we are all registered, and who exploit their children, who are obliged to beg, who are even denied the right to school. This is where the state must intervene, combating the degradation that characterises the lives of the Roma in our cities. No more hypocrisy, respect for the laws and our cultural values for integration that is not an unacceptable cancellation of differences.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, this debate on the situation of Romani inclusion in Parliament is urgently needed. COVID-19 has made the effects of anti-gypsyism visible to everyone. We are witnessing police violence against Romani people across Europe. In Bulgaria, Romania and Slovakia, we could see how the people who are locked up in their neighbourhoods had little access to food, drinking water or healthcare. In Germany, too, we are witnessing police violence against Sinti and Roma, and in Berlin there is a debate about the dismantling of the Holocaust monument to the Sinti and Roma because of a tramline: a disgrace and insult to the victims of the Holocaust.  I am the rapporteur of the House on this subject. In my current report, we express clearly our demands on the future EU-Romani policy and identify the real barriers to the inclusion of Romani people. A new approach is needed. We must put the fight against anti-gypsism and social exclusion first. Equal participation of Romani people must be achieved at all levels of government through binding targets and legislation at national, regional and local level. An adequate budget must be dedicated to the implementation of the next Romani framework. I am a Sinto, the son of a Holocaust survivor who lost six aunts and uncles in the Holocaust. I know how racism feels and I don’t want anyone to endure what me and my people have to endure on a daily basis. Unfortunately, this House had to witness racist speeches, Mr Dzhambazki, Mr Uhrík, please hold on for a moment and put your feet in our shoes and ask yourself how it feels facing racism, being degraded, insulted and beaten.  We have not only COVID-19 in Europe, but a pandemic that is older and even more dangerous: racism. We are finally prepared to confront this reality and correct this injustice. (Applause)

name: Elżbieta RAFALSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for "For centuries they have been seen as strangers. Surrounded by an atmosphere of distrust and even contempt, they were an isolated group, living on the margins of Europe's developing societies, although their contribution to cultural heritage is undeniable", is a quote from Tomasz Tomaszewski, who documented the life of the Roma and showed them to the world that the societies of these countries should take social, educational, cultural measures, giving this ethnic group due dignity and respect.  I come from a Polish region where our Roma brothers have lived and been operating for years. Here it was decided to openly appeal to gypsy culture, to cultivate the artistic traditions of the rolling stock of wajsów, Krzyżanowski, Korzeniowski, Siwaków, Jaworski, Zielinski families. Here lived the most outstanding Roma poet Papusz, here was held thirty editions of the International Meetings of Gypsy Ensembles "Romane Dyvesa" with a rich artistic program created by the outstanding Roma artist, composer and poet Edward Dębicki, who celebrated the 65th anniversary of artistic creation. Here, thanks to the creation and dissemination of Roma culture, this ethnic group enjoys due respect and recognition. I am convinced that the creative implementation of programmes on other areas of social activity, supported by a thorough knowledge of this ethnic group, is a platform for roma action in modern Europe. The point is therefore not to blindly integrate Roma into national communities. We must preserve and respect their distinctness and culture. So let's listen to them too!

name: Clare DALY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, it’s fitting for me to talk about Roma inclusion in a week when Eileen Flynn has become the first Irish Traveller to take a seat in the Irish Parliament. Let’s hope she is going to be the first of many. But for me, what’s even better about her is, I met her first when she was a campaigner for abortion rights in Ireland – not an easy position for a young Traveller woman to be in. Reproductive rights are so important for Traveller and Roma women because they face such exclusion and discrimination in many of our Member States. In Bulgaria, within maternity hospitals, Roma women are being segregated and receiving inferior treatment. In Hungary, in other countries, not been able to get reparations for forced sterilisation, and so on. In my own country, Ireland, anti—Traveller sentiment is broadly acceptable, which means that state money for Traveller housing is not spent, the Traveller Health Strategy has not been implemented in 10 years, and the Traveller Health Committee has not met in 10 years.  So, we can have all the strategies we like, but we really need implementation if we are to achieve equality.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I wonder why this situation still persists, with Roma living in ghettos where there is still great poverty, unemployment. I think that both society and the Roma must contribute to the change. And I would like to thank my colleague Peter Pollák, who is also a representative of the Roma ethnic group and is very active. He is aware of this responsibility.  I think education is the key to tearing up the chain of reproduction of poverty. We know examples of young people who have received a quality education because they were motivated, but they also had support and they need that support from society. We must eliminate racism and support their ambitions, their motivations. The European Union can also help in all this, but the Member States must also be active. Quality education, encouraging parents to have jobs, to have jobs, to be active. I think this is all a way to break the exclusion situation and help to integrate and integrate them.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: – Madam President! Strengthening roma inclusion in Europe is not only a responsibility of countries and local communities, but must be a concern for the entire European Union.  The fact that 80% of the Roma in the European Union live below the poverty line and that there is no progress in ending structural discrimination confirms that we really need a harmonised framework, and this is European, for Roma inclusion. It has reached its own level so far and, in fact, has only raised this issue on the political agenda of individual countries, and now we need a different approach.  Firstly, therefore, firstly, we must understand the diversity within the Roma community in view of the geographical and social environment and the problem of repeated discrimination against the Roma. It is also necessary to improve the socio-economic situation of the Roma in terms of employment, education, accommodation, health care, while combating the equating of this situation with Roma culture or antigipsism.  Finally, Rome needs to be integrated into all phases of national strategies, with The Slovenian assistants, a club of young university-educated Roma, and Roma saints.

name: France JAMET
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, you are asking us today for even more money for a roma integration strategy in Europe. You will not upset a multi-secular and essentially cultural situation with even more money. Nor is it up to us to bear the cost or responsibility of a life choice.  We have millions of unemployed and working poor in France, whose material situation, as you pointed out earlier, will get worse with the COVID crisis. How can I explain to my compatriots that, through a humanistic virtue and a goodness of spirit of which they are never the beneficiaries, we would choose to devote more money, more time and more means to integrate a population that does not wish to? Faced with adversity and in the crisis we are going through, we will make the choice to defend France and the French first.

name: Evin INCIR
text: – Madam President, (off mic) what the ID Group is doing right now, is actually doing what we are talking about not doing – discriminating against people, making people look like suspicious criminals who don’t want a decent life.  I think actually we should erase all of the speeches made by the ID Group until now, based on what they have been saying.  (Applause)

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: This observation had its place, but I think we have to remember that Members of Parliament have to respect each other. Indeed, Ms Jamet, you may have said something that is insulting to others. Let’s try to remember dignity and mutual respect.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, first of all, I make a remark to you about the behaviour of my colleagues in this part of the Chamber, who allow themselves to make inadmissible remarks to Members of the European Parliament. Sanction them, or I will ask for an apology from both them and you. That's first, you don't follow the Rules. Secondly, colleagues, some of you practice saying that there was discrimination in Bulgaria. Honestly, I would not comment on this, because most of you do not know where Bulgaria is on the map, you have no idea what you are talking about, you speak by heart, as usual. But I want to show you each and every one of you and invite you: come to Bulgaria to show you how to live in a small settlement where elderly people are constantly being harassed by domestic ethnic crime. Come see the ones you're protecting, come see what you're saying and prove and show what you're really doing. And now, because I heard my name here from some colleagues: a colleague, instead of shaking my head up and down, say clearly, as a man, stand up and say: are you accusing me of anything? Because if you accuse me of anything, I'il give you a chance to prove your charges in court. If you don't, it would be very cowardly and very disgraceful. You should be ashamed!

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Excuse me, I have to call for some order now. This is not a debate. You had your minute. (Voices off micro) If you have a complaint on the basis of the Rules of Procedure, you can complain to the President. We will continue. (Voices off micro) Excuse me, Mr Dzhambazki, you can make a personal statement at the end of the debate, but not now. We will move on. Please, you have to show some respect for the Chair. I am reading the Rules of Procedure. Please listen. You can make a personal statement at the end of the debate, but not now. We will continue the debate.

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: – Madam President, dear colleagues, well, we have failed our Roma citizens. We have failed collectively as Member States and as EU institutions. After one decade of Roma strategies, please remember only one figure: every third Roma child lives in a home where someone went to bed hungry at least once in the previous month. Denying this will not help. Ancient Greeks told us ‘to err is human, but to persist is diabolical’. The European Union can provide the necessary encouragement, structure and coordination to the Member States to move away from the institutional and political inaction. In Central and Eastern Europe, we need to give the highest priority to address hunger, extreme poverty and severe housing deprivation among Roma. The second most endorsed policy should be education strategies for Roma, including vocational training and adult learning. The third would be better access to the labour market. In all our societies, we need to do more to fight discrimination, to inform the public about the vulnerability of Roma, to reduce prejudices – all this is about education.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for sharing your views today. I am grateful for the dedication and support of the European Parliament for this cause.  The new strategic EU framework will promote the effective equality, inclusion and participation of Roma. It will work to combat and prevent anti—Gypsyism and discrimination, to reduce poverty and exclusion and to promote Roma participation by empowerment, cooperation and trust.  It would also be essential to increase effective access of Roma to: quality, mainstream, inclusive education; quality and sustainable employment; quality health care; and adequate desegregated housing and essential services. It is time to close the socio-economic gap between Roma and non-Roma.  With this in mind, I welcome that the German EU Presidency has placed Roma equality, inclusion and participation, on its agenda. I again thank Chancellor Merkel for making her commitment to equality, strongly and clearly in the Presidency inauguration speech here yesterday. And, of course, I also count on the strong support of Parliament in the work ahead of us.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. I am very grateful to have taken part in this debate today, because it shows that we agree to a great extent and that we also know how difficult the task ahead is. But if we tackle this together with great courage and commitment, I am sure that by the end of this year we will have a strategy from which we will all emerge stronger.  We, as the Presidency, also want to make a concrete contribution to this. We want to organise a conference. I fear that this conference will only be able to take place virtually under the prevailing conditions, but it is another opportunity for exchanges, especially here in Parliament and in the other institutions, but above all with those directly affected. I am amazed at something I have not only heard here. Dealing with Roma is not about hospitality. The vast majority of Roma are citizens of our countries. (Applause) They enjoy the same rights and duties as all of us. They are not guests, and so it is already part of the discrimination that Roma and Sinti are subjected to if they are segregated or excluded from a society of free and equal. Moreover, ladies and gentlemen, it is not about privileges. It is about something very simple: it is about equal rights and equality with six million citizens of the European Union. name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – The Roma people, with some six million inhabitants in the EU, are one of the largest ethnic minorities in Europe. Unfortunately, a significant part of its population still lives in very precarious socio-economic conditions.  The creation of the current European Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies until 2020 was considered a milestone and represented a turning point for Europe's Roma communities. However, as a non-binding political tool, it provides a framework for political coordination, consultation and monitoring and specific policy recommendations for national Roma integration strategies, but its translation into specific administrative capacities and policy actions is at the discretion of national, regional and local governments. In order to correct this problem, the adoption of a Directive for equality and inclusion of persons of Roma origin is necessary for the new decade. A binding legislative act for Member States that includes clear objectives, is tailored to the needs of each particular context, has specific indicators, more efficient and robust monitoring and monitoring mechanisms, and adequate funding.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Strategies for Roma integration have been numerous, particularly under European leadership. This includes the creation in 2004 of the European Roma and Travellers Forum, as well as in 2010 a European Commission communication complemented by a comprehensive strategy in 2011. In this context, the Eastern European States have undoubtedly made a number of efforts, particularly in the area of access to higher education. However, while the European framework of action set a first deadline in 2020, it is clear that the failure is obvious. Who's to blame? Rather than throwing anathema at the states concerned, let us recognize that there are many reasons. For example, school segregation is partly due to the withdrawal of non-Roma children from schools by their parents. Similarly, cultural factors, such as early marriage or child labour, must be taken into account, even if it would be very minority. In 2014, EU Commissioner Viviane Reding conceded that "it is also up to the Roma to seek integration and a normal way of life." So we have to take into account all the responsibilities.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: Writing. – In 2011, the Hungarian Government was the only one to convince the members of the Council of the importance of integrating the poorest, as was the case with the epidemic. The Commission finally recognises the importance of the points requested in the EP report, which has been voiced since 2004 and which won 97% support in 2010, as an essential condition for successful Roma integration. The failure in 2011 to fully support the main cornerstones of my report and the proposals of our government has greatly de-tripped successful Roma integration in our Member States.  The main areas of expertise, housing, health, education, work, digitalisation, green energy use, agriculture, subsidiarity and real Roma organisations, the priority of local initiatives, were an integral part of our proposals at the time. I am convinced that their absence, pointing to the unpreparedness of the Roma team of the commission at the time, is a major cause of the worse-than-expected results of today's Roma strategies.  I consider the right to equal education to be important, stressing the importance of exchanging existing good practices between countries. The number of segregated classes in Hungary has decreased from 1400 to 600 in the last ten years. Poverty decreased by 35%, which was contributed by kindergarten and crèche construction programmes, Safe Start Children's Homes in the poorest regions, family centres with one child, tax breaks for mothers with large families, housing and car purchase assistance. Across Europe, Roma problems are similar in nature – m.in. low level of education, absence from the labour market, significantly shorter life expectancy, segregation in education, poor housing, difficult access to basic public services. The impact of intracultural factors on the situation of Roma (e.g. premature marriages and premature motherhood) which perpetuate the marginalisation of this community is often underestimated.  Almost all European countries implement roma assistance programmes in the form of integration-centred actions taking into account the specificities of this group (taylored policies) or under the so-called mainstream policy.  Despite taking steps for many years, the situation of this group has not improved significantly. It is therefore necessary to continue the efforts of states for integration, with a particular indication of improving formal education, including, in particular, with regard to Roma youth and, in particular, vocational education.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the Statement by the Council and the Commission on the situation in the Council negotiations on the regulation on the protection of the Union budget in the face of general deficiencies in the rule of law in the Member States (2020/2709(RSP)).

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Perhaps, at the beginning of my speech, Let me say something and make it clear that seems to be self-evident in all our ears. The European Union is not primarily an internal market or a monetary community, we are, above all, and first and foremost, a community of law and values. These principles, which are based on our treaties and are written down in our treaties, bind us all. Thank you, honourable Members, for giving me the opportunity to inform you of the current state of play in the negotiations in the Council on the regulation on the protection of the Union's budget in the event of general shortcomings in the rule of law in the Member States. This proposal was an integral part of the political pact, the package that the Commission presented on 2 May 2018 on the next Multiannual Financial Framework. As such, it will be dealt with by the Council in the context of the negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework. The in-depth examination of the proposal began in November 2018. It's been a long time coming. It quickly became apparent that two elements are particularly sensitive for delegations in the Council: firstly, the link with the rule of law and, secondly, the voting mode for approving the measures. In the Presidency's view, no progress could be made on these points without the political guidance of the Heads of State or Government in the Council. These issues were therefore included in the draft negotiating box drawn up by the Austrian Presidency. The Romanian Presidency continued its technical deliberations on other elements of the proposal. It presented a total of five Presidency compromise proposals, which were discussed at both technical and political level. A detailed overview of the process and the main elements of the consultation can be found in the progress report of the Romanian Presidency. The President of the European Council has set himself the task of obtaining a clear picture of the views of the Heads of State or Government as part of the discussions on the overall MFF package on the Commission proposal. To this end, in February 2020, it presented a draft European Council conclusions, and, as you know, this work is still ongoing. Without european Council guidance on the policy elements identified in the examination of the proposal, there is little scope for further work at technical level. As soon as these European Council policy guidelines are in place – and we hope that this will happen as soon as possible – the Presidency will immediately start work on the legislative text so that negotiations with the European Parliament can begin as soon as possible. In this context, President Michel informed you yesterday of preparations for the forthcoming European Council. As the proposals are part of the entire MFF package, it is necessary to ensure that the negotiations conducted under the ordinary legislative procedure do not delay the negotiations aimed at ensuring the European Parliament's approval of the MFF regulation. I would ask for leniency for the complicated remarks, but it is a difficult dossier and that is why I wanted to inform you with the greatest possible transparency about this procedure and about the discussions in the Council.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the summit next week marks an important moment for Europe and, as we have seen throughout Europe, as each of us has felt in his or her own country and constituency, corona has changed our way of life and the economy. This unprecedented challenge is the moment when Europe matters more than ever. The lives of millions of people, the future of hundreds of thousands of companies and the prospects of many regions depend on our recovery plan. This makes it even more important that every euro we invest via our common EU budget really adds value and becomes a true investment in our future. Europeans expect us to protect taxpayers’ money and interests. Rightly so. The rule of law regulation plays an important role here and I appreciate this debate right before the summit. So let me highlight three points. First, where there are cases of generalised rule of law deficiencies in a Member State, we need an effective instrument to protect taxpayers’ money. Our rule of law proposal creates a genuine budgetary protection mechanism. Second, it’s a targeted tool to protect the European Union budget. That means that it’s fully in line with the Treaties and it’s distinct from the mechanism under Article 7 of the Treaties.  Third, it’s an objective and transparent budgetary mechanism to protect sound financial management. Measures will be proportionate to the impact on the EU budget and the position of the Member State concerned will be duly considered. The burden of proof will be borne by the Commission and the Council. The measures will need to be based on concrete factual elements and on specific grounds. So I thank Parliament once again for its support for the Commission’s proposal through the legislative resolution of 4 April 2019. The points raised by Parliament were well noted, notably the need to ensure the protection of final recipients and beneficiaries. It’s important that they don’t pay the price for rule of law deficiencies. The Commission is committed to addressing these issues in the trilogues.  The scope of our proposal is clear. It establishes a genuine mechanism to protect the EU budget and ensure sound financial management. In November 2019, the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) and the Committee on Budgets (BUDG) already decided to enter into interinstitutional negotiations with the Council. I trust that trilogues can start swiftly under the German Presidency and I took note, with great pleasure, of the statement of the Council representative. I count on the continued support of Parliament to find an agreement that preserves the effectiveness and the ambition of this important proposal. Protecting our common budget is our common interest. The rule of law proposal is a key feature of the overall MFF negotiations and therefore time is of the essence. Only if you, honourable Members, and the European Council strive for an overall political MFF agreement in the summer will we have a chance of getting support to where it is needed. I know this is indeed very ambitious and would represent an unprecedented speed. Well, these are unprecedented times. I think that for citizens, companies and regions every day counts and we have to deliver. This is in all our interests.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, one and a half years ago actually, Parliament already reached its position on the regulation on the protection of the Union’s budget in case of generalised deficiencies as regards the rule of law in the Member States. This rule of law mechanism would be a huge leap and enable the EU to protect our values, as well as our taxpayers’ money and the Union budget, from misuse and fraud. This Parliament has a solid stance. We need a strong rule of law mechanism. It is somewhat worrying that the bits of information we have received from the Council hint that there are still disagreements within the Council even on the very basic idea of the regulation. We, as the European Parliament, have called on the Council to engage in meaningful talks about its ongoing negotiations. We stress that we will not simply rubber-stamp a fait accompli without carrying out proper negotiations. So, a question to the Council remains: will your level of ambition match ours?

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner Han, Minister Roth, I am glad and pleased to hear yesterday that the Presidency has among its priorities the defence of fundamental rights, and we share the importance of respect from the rule of law as a fundamental aspect of European construction, and as the main acquis communautaire. You said it: we are a Union of rights and values.  And if we are in this debate today, it is precisely because we want to stress that, for the European Parliament, this is not only a priority, but is a necessary condition for the proper conduct of the budgetary negotiations that we will have in the coming months.  The European Parliament has clearly expressed its position on the Commission's proposal. Not only is respect for the rule of law important, but we must ensure compliance with all aspects to which, in fact and in law, Member States commit themselves when they sign their accession to the European Union. That is why we are talking about equality, solidarity, combating tax evasion or unfair competition in tax matters.  Chancellor Merkel, yesterday in her speech, referred to the need to work with the European Parliament to protect the common Europe. "Together, re-strengthen Europe," he said. And you've emphasized it, too. Well, here we are, ready to negotiate with the Council. And I would like to stress the 'negotiate' thing, because they have to negotiate this regulation with Parliament. We are not here to support any agreement that leaves the Council. They must negotiate with the European Parliament in order to continue to build together that common Europe which is a reference in the world of respect and defence of fundamental values.

text: Mr President, i.e. the Renew Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. The Chancellor yesterday began her speech with a strong appeal to fundamental rights in the European Union. That was also good, and that was the right thing to do. But this also requires a consequence of the Chancellor to now also work for this rule of law and for this rule of law mechanism at the summit. Because the EU is indeed more than the internal market, it is a community of values.
