text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It is clear that the law is based on the Treaties and we support those rule of law initiatives in the Union that are in line with the letter and spirit of the Treaties and take into account that, in accordance with the principle of conferral, the Union acts only within the limits of the powers conferred on it by the Member States in the Treaties to achieve the objectives set out therein, and that any competence not conferred on the Union by the Treaties belongs to the Member States.  Unfortunately, the planned mechanism linking the EU budget to the rule of law is not precise and does not guarantee legal certainty for Member States. The conditionality of spending must be based on objective, specific, measurable and adequate criteria. It must not reach closer to unspecified catalogues of sources of threats or phobias presented by the left side of the stage in Parliament. Unfortunately, the proposed draft regulation does not meet these criteria and leaves too much discretion. It is political, not legal or economic.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the opposite of the rule of law is arbitrary and dictatorship, and therefore the rule of law is a fundamental values of the European Union. That is why we need a mechanism to ensure that European funds are not directed to countries that do not respect the rule of law. This is our duty to the taxpayer. If there is no independent judiciary in the country, there is no guarantee that suspected abuses can be investigated or addressed.  At the same time, we are now deciding on a long financial framework and an exceptionally large stimulus package, and among its main beneficiaries are countries whose rule of law development we have been concerned about for a long time. It is therefore necessary for the new financial framework to include a conditionality clause to ensure that all Member States respect democracy, the freedom and legality of their citizens. All of these are fundamental principles of the rule of law. If they do not respect, it must be possible to freeze the funds. If the Union does not adhere strictly to the rule of law, we will no longer be the community of values as it was founded. Therefore, new decisions should not be taken unless decisions are taken at the same time to protect the rule of law.

name: Mario FURORE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe must have serious legislation that guarantees the rule of law through certain rules that do not give rise to discretion.  We do not want this valuable instrument to be used for political purposes. That is why I call on the Council and the Commission to provide for clear and certain rules, with criteria for defining violations of the rule of law that are clearly defined and based on measurable and verifiable indicators, as well as preventive monitoring of problems, on an annual basis. We do not want further restrictions linked to macro-conditionality to be imposed under the rule of law, but we do want to guarantee the principles of legality, legal certainty and the independence of the judiciary. We are therefore prepared to support a text that is an effective instrument to ensure that the values of Europe and its citizens are protected.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, I will not use my minute to attack someone from the left or the right. I don't think that's what this debate is about, colleagues. And always the way this place goes wrong, either against Fidész or against the Socialists, it takes away our legitimacy to negotiate anything with the Council. Let us go consensually as the whole Parliament. We want to have the principle that if in one country – and whoever rules, we will in no way defend it, which is on either side – in one state universal human rights will cease to be respected, that state cannot receive our general support in funding. That is why we are calling the Council, why we are calling out to the Commission: 'Let us start negotiations'. Colleagues, let us stop fighting in these debates and let us direct our efforts towards the Council and let us finally sit down at the table. I think the subject is more important than whether there's one or the other.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by greeting Minister Roth. I know it is a matter of dear to you, and therefore we are counting on you to defend the rule of law. Any country wishing to become a candidate for the European Union must comply with the so-called Copenhagen criteria and therefore respect the rule of law. You cannot abandon that requirement when you become a Member State. This is the European Union we want.  We need to ensure that the financial contribution of citizens to the European project is even applied in the European project. It is therefore necessary to adopt a powerful new mechanism, which will enable action to be adopted whenever the rule of law is violated, that protects beneficiaries, that respects the institutional powers of the European Parliament, including in budgetary matters. Finally, we must protect democracy and the rule of law and ensure that European taxpayers' money is well used to defend European policies and values.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Madam President, this new budget is a perfect chance for the European Union to finally move beyond lip service, to put our money where our mouths are, to place our European values at the heart of our European budget. Renew Europe put a  sound and thorough proposition on the table. Our Smart Conditionality Mechanism is a perfect way to ensure that corrupted governments who violate the rule of law are punished but final beneficiaries – NGOs, local governments, the people – are not. It entails three very simple steps: monitor, freeze and reroute. Monitoring through mandatory membership in the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, freezing funds in case of systemic breaches, and redirecting them to final beneficiaries, with direct control by the Commission. Let me add something to the political difficulties that are being discussed so often by the Council. There is a narrative that a conflict of interest exists between Member States, and I believe this is largely a misconception. Of course there is a conflict of interest, but it’s between the Heads of States and Governments, and they do not equal their Member States. Prime Minister Orbán does not equal Hungary. So I would be curious to hear who the Council chooses to represent, because I believe that the Council should be representing the people, the small businesses, the NGOs, the local governments, the people in need, and they should be the recipients of a direct EU funding from the Commission. Because, colleagues, how can we trust governments that misuse their powers, who do not respect EU values and fuel corruption? How can we trust them to spend our European money effectively? I think the answer is clear: we cannot, and we should not.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I believe that no one in this room is questioning the rule of law. The rule of law is a principle that must be observed, and it is also respected.  What is a problem, however, is the combination of the rule of law with a mechanism that may not apply evenly to everyone. I see a problem, a contradiction, also with the other principles such as the principle of democracy or the principle of subsidiarity. We must be careful that, in the fight against individual things that really need to be combated – for which, incidentally, we also have authorities such as OLAF, such as the European Public Prosecutor's Office and other authorities, including the Court of Auditors – we do not come to a Lex Orban, which then binds everyone else and ultimately fails to achieve the objective for which it is intended.  That is why we are careful not to overshoot the mark here.

name: Clara PONSATÍ OBIOLS
text: – Madam President, the EU budget must be protected against violations of the rule of law, but to be effective and fair across Member States this conditionality must be based on objective criteria. Violations of the rule of law take many dimensions, but a minimal objective threshold that all democrats recognise is that holding political prisoners is incompatible with the rule of law. Amnesty International and the United Nations Working Group on Arbitrary Detention have ruled that the Catalan leaders that Spain keeps in prison are political prisoners and they must be released. The Spanish authorities have not obeyed this demand. As long as Spain continues to defy the United Nations and keep this warfare against the Catalan minority, the rule of law is upset in Spain.  It is not fair to look only at the East, the rule of law is violated in the West. If you care about democracy and human rights, please do look at Spain as well.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has What strikes me here at the moment is that everyone is taking out a country that they particularly dislike. But that would be a fundamental misunderstanding of the rule of law.  For me, the rule of law means that we have basic standards and that if these standards are not respected, we will also be given the opportunity, Commissioner, to be able to consistently impose penalties and take action without looking at the party, the person and the country. I do not care at all whether it is Mr Muscat, whether it is Mr Orban, whether it is Mr Babié – we have some problem cases in different party families. We have different problems within the rule of law. What we need to do, for example – and I would like to make this very clear – is that we must carry out systemic checks by actually systematically checking how certain rule of law mechanisms work, by systematically checking how certain rule of law mechanisms work, how, for example, .B calls for tenders are taking place and whether they are taking place in favour of certain undertakings in certain environments. We need to be able to have disclosure of economic beneficiaries and to be able to connect with a real-time information system in which it makes serious sense to be able to actually check everything, to be able to look at it and not to have to search for months.  I would ask us not to act in a partisan way, but simply by standards and measures. Then we will be credible.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her This important issue: why is it so important to protect European values through financial consequences? Firstly, because every European Member State has committed itself to these European values by acceding.  Secondly, unfortunately, because they are no longer self-evident. More and more Member States are happy to receive the subsidies, but are no longer obliged to the independence of the judiciary, the freedom of the media and the separation of powers.  Thirdly, because the EU cannot function without respect for these values. Neither the internal market nor the free movement of workers are conceivable without effective legal protection before any court in each Member State. Fourthly, because all European citizens have a right to have their taxpayers' money not in the pockets of governments that do not want to abide by these values. Fifthly, unfortunately, because these governments do not seem to understand any language other than that of money. Dear Council, Thank you very much for the work she has You are sure of all the support of Parliament to protect our values by including conditionality and annual objective monitoring.  But you can also be sure that if you want to prevent, dilute, or render as unusable as possible, you will encounter decisive resistance – whoever tries to do so. Effective protection of our values serves all the citizens of the European Union.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: Madam President, Minister Roth, Commissioner Reynders, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work. More than two years ago, the Commission put its proposal on the table, and for a year now the position of this Parliament has also been very well known. But the Council still seems to be in a slumber and enjoying it. Never before has the rule of law been in such poor condition in so many Member States. Never before has so much taxpayers' money been at stake. The Council's inaction fills the pockets of the autocrats unchecked. Your inaction makes you complicit in those who trample on our fundamental rights. For us, the preservation of the rule of law is not a negotiating material with the MFF, but a prerequisite for benefiting from European funds. I am counting on the German Presidency, Mr Roth, to ensure that EU money is received by citizens, farmers and SMEs – where they are most needed, and not where they are most shamelessly abused.

name: Lara WOLTERS
text: Mr President, Minister Roth, our European democracy is fragile. A number of oligarchs and populists in Europe are in the process of breaking down the rule of law step by step, and they are also weakening the authorities in their countries that have to oversee the distribution of European subsidies. Members of the Committee on Budgetary Control are now familiar with the tricks. It's not a coincidence, of course. These oligarchs and those populists, I do not have to mention their names – I think – they do everything they can to ensure that European subsidies can enrich their own clique, and then it is so useful of course if no one is watching.  That is why such a rule of law mechanism is such an important proposal. With such a mechanism, we can hand out sanctions if there are doubts about national control. I therefore call on the Member States to recognise colour and support this proposal. Whatever happens next week, stand up for European democracy and stand for the rule of law. Stand up for European taxpayers, who have never signed up for corruption.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Because we, the European Union, are a community of values and the rule of law, it is a disgrace that the Member States have so far been unable to agree on a rule of law mechanism, they have wanted to agree and thereby block it. The citizens – we – are fed up with the mere demands and announcements and consolations. The Member States must finally get their heads around it. Only nails with heads can regain lost trust and lost credibility. I would therefore like to make it quite clear to us that we must not channel funds to countries and companies and individuals who trample on EU law.  Therefore, the rule of law mechanism must be part of the use of funds for Next Generation EU and the next year's long-term budget. It must be part of the overall package. Respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights is a priority – not only for the German Presidency, not only for the Austrian Federal Government, for all of us, because it is the basis of this Community.

name: Didier Reynders
text: membre de la Commission. – Madame la Présidente, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, tout d’abord, merci beaucoup pour ce débat. Je suis ravi d’entendre que nous sommes pleinement d’accord sur l’importance de protéger le budget de l’Union. Votre soutien à cet égard, vous le savez, est essentiel. Le respect de l’état de droit est une condition préalable fondamentale au respect du principe de bonne gestion financière. The reasoning of our proposal is simple. In order to control the use of EU funds and to protect the financial interests of the EU against corruption and fraud, we need in each Member State independent justice systems, effective investigation and prosecution services and an effective functioning of public authorities implementing the Union budget. If those functions are endangered by a generalised deficiency of the rule of law in a Member State, the Union would be empowered to suspend, reduce or restrict access to EU funding in a proportionate manner.  Let me also stress that the proposed mechanism ensures the fairness and objectivity of the process. It will give adequate consideration to the views of the Member States concerned and will guarantee the proportionality of the measures taken. Moreover, the measures adopted will be subject to the full judicial review of the Court of Justice.  Par ailleurs, le mécanisme doit rester rapide et efficace. Il est donc essentiel que les modalités de vote au sein du Conseil soient celles de la majorité qualifiée inversée, comme proposé par la Commission. Cela garantirait une adoption rapide des mesures proposées. There is currently no instrument to protect the EU budget against generalised deficiencies as regards the rule of law in a Member State. The creation of this mechanism would decidedly improve the protection of the EU budget. Filling this significant gap is more important than ever, given the increased funding and increased flexibility proposed by the Commission in reaction to the COVID-19 crisis. We need to protect this funding in the very interest of all taxpayers and all citizens of the Union. La Commission reste fermement déterminée à contribuer à la recherche d’un compromis et invite le Parlement et le Conseil à conclure rapidement un accord sur cette importante proposition ainsi que sur un nouveau cadre financier pluriannuel. Il est dans notre intérêt à tous de finaliser rapidement un accord pour que le nouveau budget pluripluriannuel soit opérationnel à partir du 1er janvier 2021. L’Union doit se donner les moyens d’une reprise durable pour soutenir les citoyens, les entreprises et les régions les plus touchés par la crise. Nous le devons également aux futures générations. Le plan de relance qui est sur la table est l’occasion pour l’Europe de devenir plus résiliente, plus verte et plus numérique, mais aussi plus ambitieuse dans la protection de ses valeurs. La Commission fera tout son possible pour ouvrir la voie à un accord rapide et ambitieux entre les colégislateurs. I want to say to the Council, to Minister Roth, that we are ready to engage in the discussions in the trilogue to make progress in the protection of the budget of the European Union and in the defence of our values. (Applause)

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Who is afraid of controversy? You do not, but I promise you, nor do the Council. You all know what it is all about. Europe is built not only on consensus, but also on controversy, and our constitutional mothers and constitutional fathers of a united Europe could not have imagined decades ago that we would ever find ourselves in a situation of having to seriously check whether the principles of the rule of law apply equally in all EU Member States. I would like to take up what Mrs Hohlmeier has said here: it is a question of equal treatment. The Council attaches the utmost importance to ensuring that all Member States are treated equally, that all Member States are reviewed. If Mr Freund doubts the integrity of the Presidency, I would like to remind you once again, not only what the Chancellor said yesterday for the Presidency, but what we have kindly already sent you, namely the Presidency programme. It contains a sentence which I am sure the Commissioner should also be pleased with: 'We therefore support the Commission's proposal to link EU budgets with compliance with the rule of law in the Member States'. That is what it is all about, and it is not enough for us. In this respect, I can only tell you, Mr Wolters, that the Council is not in a slumber, we are a sham. I can only tell you that, and when it comes to us – and this is the Presidency's proposal – we in the Council will deal with the situation of the rule of law in the European Union in almost every sitting in this Presidency. We will also use the European Commission's planned report on the rule of law as an opportunity to maintain an objective, but certainly not indisputable, exchange. I hope that we will succeed in this. In this respect, ladies and gentlemen, I am very grateful to all of you for the encouragement you have given us. I see a high degree of agreement, but since it is embedded in the negotiations on the multiannual financial framework, you all know much better than I do that everything is somehow related to everything. We are not talking in isolation about one area, but you can still be sure that the Chancellor's words will also be heard up to the European Council, namely that it will be made clear: this is not just about money, but really about what holds us together at its core, and in this respect I can take the question from Mr Sarvamaa and also Mr Körner's question. , whether we have enough ambition to answer with a clear and explicit 'yes'. Political rebates are not granted to anyone, and so I look forward to future consultations with you. There is a great deal at stake, but it is also about the unity of the European Union, which is based on common values – and the rule of law is a very important one of them.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Thank you, Mrs Roth, and I wish you every success in the negotiations. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – One cannot but be supportive of measures to promote and enforce the rule of law in the European Union. However, there exists as yet no agreed, concrete rulebook by which to assess the practice of the rule of law in the different member states. So assessments remain quite dependent on subjective political criteria that are not – perhaps cannot – be applied uniformly and equally to all. What constitutes a breach of the rule of law is still open to interpretation that too often discriminates between Member States. Moreover, the implementation of rule of law provisions including decisions to apply sanctions can only be as objective as possible if the agency that applies them is independent of all other agencies in the Union, has a quasi-judicial status and the power to investigate cases of infringement as they arise. This does not seem to be the case as things stand at present. It is extremely doubtful whether such a role should be assigned to the European Commission (or its nominee) given its executive and political status. A final point to keep in mind is whether budgetary sanctions as envisaged would not end up hurting most citizens who might themselves be the victims of alleged rule of law breaches.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Since the European Commission opened the first infringement proceedings against Poland and Hungary, the rule of law in the Union has continued to deteriorate seriously, not only in the above-mentioned Member States, but also in others, which poses a serious threat to our community as a whole – a Union of values based on the rule of law and mutual trust.  In Poland, the PiS government has been constantly attacking the Constitutional Court, the Supreme Court, independent media, as well as individual social groups and minorities for five years, with the aim of specifically electing LGBTI people and migrants and migrant women. The situation in Hungary has also not improved. In recent years, the orbán-led government has cut funding for civic organisations, systematically marginalised the LGBTI community, abolished media pluralism and continued to fight academic freedom and freedom of expression. Nevertheless, neither Polish nor Hungary have faced any consequences for violations of the rule of law.  In 2018, we welcomed the Commission's proposal to link respect for the rule of law to EU funds. However, neither the Council nor the Commission has made sufficient efforts to actually implement this mechanism. That is why today we call on both the Council and the Commission to take more decisive action to stop the European rule of law crisis before it reaches the point where there will be no more return.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. – Linking the principles of the rule of law with the benefit of EU budgetary resources goes against the original intentions of the Treaties on the rule of law. This set of requirements was originally designed to improve the democratic and efficient functioning of the EU institutions, as drafted by the TSI, so that they can better perform the tasks assigned to them within a single institutional framework. Instead, EU actors call for the rule of law in a Member State by deciding on purely political aspects in their investigations, while the original recipients of the set of requirements, the functioning of the EU institutions, are not subject to any rule of law assessment at all. By enforcing the rule of law, the EU intends to have a say in member states' own democratic and sovereign decision-making. According to Article 4 TSI, any competence which the Treaties have not conferred on the Union shall remain with the Member States and the Union shall respect the national identity of the Member States, which is an integral part of their fundamental political and constitutional system. The Union may act only within the limits of the powers delegated to it by the Member States in order to achieve the objectives of the Treaties (Article 5). The current rule of law policy persects a sensitive compromise between Member States on the transfer of sovereignty by forcing the EU to have a say in any political decision of the Member States on this issue, while not doing its original task of holding the EU institutions accountable in the field of the rule of law.

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: Writing. – There are often declarations in Parliament that proceedings against Poland and Hungary are directed against their governments and their alleged democratic deficits, not against the countries and their citizens. The proposal, which would punish Member States by suspending payments from the EU budget, reveals that such a vigorous separation is rather an illusion and is very difficult to implement in practice. This is especially true of the recovery package after the epidemic, which is increasingly proving to be political, not only reflecting the effects of the epidemic, but also other vested interests. Surely there can be no object to Parliament's supervisory function in protecting taxpayers' money from corruption and enrichment of politicians and their loved ones. However, there are reasonable doubts about the assessment of democracy and the rule of law in the countries concerned and their financial sanctioning. Not so long ago, Parliament, in a resolution, overwhelmingly condemned Hungary's measures on the coronavirus epidemic, only for the European Commission to subsequently find that they complied with EU legislation and not even to start infringement proceedings against Hungary. Either way, cohesion and other funds are not a form of reward for good government behavior.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: We shall now proceed to the third voting time. We shall vote on the dossiers on the agenda. Before I begin, I give the floor to Mr Tardino, who has asked to speak under Rule 159(4) on his report on the conclusion of an EU-New Zealand agreement, which is being negotiated, on the exchange of personal data to combat serious crime and terrorism.

name: Annalisa TARDINO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking all my colleagues and shadow rapporteurs for their work on this report, the purpose of which is to highlight the Recommendations of the European Parliament with a view to the negotiations for the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and New Zealand on the exchange of personal data between Europol and the New Zealand authorities responsible for combating crime and terrorism. As we are all aware, terrorism is still a serious threat today and the fight against these criminal acts is a top priority, not only for the European Union but for all the Member States. Too many victims have wept in recent years, fellow citizens who have fatally become the random object of unprecedented hatred and violence, and we owe our commitment to them. New Zealand's inclusion among the countries with which to engage in cooperation stems from the Christchurch attack in March 2019, also considering that the European Union and New Zealand are partners that share the same principles, vision and approaches on many global issues. To date, Europol and the New Zealand police have signed a working agreement providing a framework for structured cooperation, but there is still no legal basis, which is essential for detecting, preventing and prosecuting terrorist offences. In my report I set out a number of objectives that will have to be pursued during the negotiations in order to allow the use and transfer of personal data for security reasons, while at the same time guaranteeing the protection of people's fundamental rights.  From this point of view, I believe that the text that will be put to the vote represents the right combination of the two requirements, reminding us that the fight against terrorism and its international dimension deserve all our attention and our political and legislative commitment, and I hope that this House will be able to give concrete recognition to it tomorrow.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Voting time will be open from 6.30 p.m. until 7.45 p.m. The votes will take place in the same way as at the previous voting time. I therefore declare the third voting time open. You have until 7.45 p.m. to vote, ladies and gentlemen. The results of the third round of voting will then be announced tomorrow at 9.00 a.m. The sitting will be closed at 7.45 p.m. at the end of the third voting session and will resume tomorrow at 9.00 a.m.
